div.l: First on þe wal was peyntid a forest
In wich there dwellith nethir man ne best
With knotty and knarry brekyn̄ treis old
Of stobbis sharp and hidous to be hold
In wich ran a swymbil in a swowe
As thogh it a storm̄ were shuld brest eủery bowe
And downward on an hiƚƚ vndir a bent
There stode the Tempil of Marce Armipotent
Wroght al of burnyd stele the wich thentre
Was long and streite and gladly for to se
And ther͗e out cam a rage and such a voise
That it made al the gatis for to reyse
The Northeryn̄ light in atte dor shone
For wyndowe on þe wal was there non̄
Thorow wich men myght ony light dissern̄
The doris were al of Athamaundis etern̄
Inclosid ovirtwart and Euenlong
With Iren̄ for to make it strong
Every Peloure the Tempil to susteyne
Was ton grete of Iren̄ bright and shene
There sawe I first the derk Imagenyng
Of felony and al the compassing
The cruel Ire rede as ony glede
The Pikpurs and eke the pale rede
The smyler with the knyfe vndir the cloke
The shepyn̄ brennyng with þe blak smoke
The tresoıı̄un of the mordring in the bed
The opyn̄ werris with woundis al bled
Contek with blody knyfe and sharp manase
Al ful of chirkyng was the sory plase
The sleer of hym ꝫit sawe I there
His hert blode hath batid al his here
The nayle Idryve in the shode an hiꝫte
The cold deth with mowith gaping vp right
Amyddil of the Tempil sat myschᵃunse
With discomfort and sory contenaunce
Ꝫit sawe I woodnes laghing in his rag
The hunt stranglid with þe wild borys corage
The sowe freting the Child in the Cradil
The Cook Iskaldid for al his long ladil
Nat was forꝫetyn̄ the infortune of marce
The Carter ovir͗ ridyn̄ with his own̄ hors
Vndir the whele ful lowe he lay a down̄
There were also of mattris devicioun̄
The Barbour͗e þe boteler and þe smyth
That forgith sharp swerdis in her stith
And al above depeyntid in a toure
The high conquest sitting in grete honoure
With the sharp swerd ovir͗ his hede
Hanging be a subtil twynyd threde
Depeyntid was there þe slaghtir of Iulius
Of grete Nero and of Antonius
Al be that tyme þey were vnborn̄
Ꝫit was her deth depeyntid there beforn̄
Be manysshing of marce right be fegure
So was hit shewid right be portreture
As it is depeyntid in the Certris above
Who shal be sleyn and who shal be dede for love
Suffisith on ensaumpil in storyis old
I may nat rekyn̄ al they that I wold
The statu of marce oppon̄ a cart stode
Armyd and lokid grym̄ as he were wode
And ovir͗ his hede there shynyn̄ to feguris
The tone Puella the tothir͗ Rubius
This God of Armys was arayid thus
A wolf there stode be forn̄ hym at his fete
With yꝫen̄ rede and of a man he ete
With subtil pensel was depeyntid his story
In redowting of marce and of his glory
Nowe to the Tempil of Dyane þe chast
As shortly as I can̄ I wol me hast
To tel ꝫewe al the discripcioun̄
Depeyntid on the wallis vp and down̄
Of hunting and of shamefast chastit
There sawe I howe woful calistope
When that Diane grevid was with her
Was turnyd from̄ a womman to Abere
And aftir was she made the lode stere
Thus was it peyntid I can sey no fer
Her son̄ is eke a ster as men may se
There sawe I Dyan̄ turnyd vntil a tre
I mene it nat the goddes Dyane
But Peneus doghter wich þat hiꝫt Dyane
There sawe I Atheon̄ an hert Imakid
For vengeaunce þat he sawe Dyane al nakid
I sawe howe þat houndis have hym caght
And fretid hym̄ for þat þey knewe hym naght
Ꝫit Ipeyntid was alitil ferthermore
Howe Artalaunce huntid þe wild bore
And meliagr͗e and many a nothir͗ mo
For wich Dyane wroght hym care ⁊and woo
There sawe I many a nothir wondir͗ story
The wich me list nat to drawe in memory
This goddes an an hert ful hiꝫe is set
With smale houndis about her fete
And vndir neth her fete she had a mone
Wexing it was and shuld vany sone
I gaudy grene her statu clothid was

Her yꝫen kist she ful lowe a down̄
There Pluto hath his derk Regyoun̄
A vomman traveling was her be forn̄
But for her Child so long was vnborn̄
Ful petously lucyna gan she cal
And seid help for thowe maist best of al
Wele coud he peynt lyvely that it vroght
With many a floren̄ he these hewis vroght
Nowe ben̄ these listis made and Theseus
That at his grete cost hath araid thus
The Tempil and the Autris every dele
When it was done hit likid hym̄ right wele

And speke of Palamon and Arcite
The day approchith of her atourneyng

For every white þat lovid Chyvalry

For yf there fil to morowe such a case

Weer it as thik as a braunchid oke
And what man it woundith with þe stroke
He shal neure be hole tyl ȝowe lust of grace
To stroke hym with the plat in þe same plase
Ther he is hurt that is as mykil to seyn̄
Ȝee mot with the plat sword ageyn̄
Stroke hym in the wound and it wol close
This is a verry soth with outyn glose
It fayleth not whilis it is in ȝour͗e hold
And when this knyght hath thus his tale I told
He rood out of hall and down he lite
His Stede wich that shone as þe son̄ bright
Stont in the court ful as ony stone
This knyght in to the chambir is led anon̄
And is vn armyd and to mete I set
The presentis ben richily kept
This is to sey the swerd and the myrrour͗e
Been born Anon in to the toure
With certen officers ordynyd therfore
And to Canace the ryng is bore
Solempnly ther͗e she sit at the table
But sikirly with outyn ony fabil
The hors of bras that may nat be remeuid
Hit stont as it were to the ground I beuid
There may no man out of the plase it dryue
For non engyns of wyndas ne polyue
And cause why for they con nat the craft And ꝑperfo
And þerfor in the place they haue it laft
Til þat þe knyght haue taght hem þe manere
To voydyn hym as yee shul aftir here
Grete was the prese that swarmyd to ⁊and fro
To gawryn on the hors that stode so
For it so hiȝe was so brood and long
So wele poroyonyd to be strong
Right as it were asteede of lumbardy
There with so horsly quyk and hyȝe
As it agentil Poyleyn corser were
For certis from his tayle vn to his here
Nature ne art ne coud hym nat amend
In no Degre as al the pepil wend
But euir more her most wondir was
Howe þat it coud goo and was of bras
Hit was a fayre as al the pepil semed
Diuers folk diuersly they Demeyd
As many heuis as many wittis there bene
They mormedon as don a swarm of bene
And made skillis aftir her fantesy
Rehersyng of the old poyetry
And seyd it was like the Pegasee
The hors þat had wyngis for to fle
Or ellis it was the Grekis hors Synoun
That broght Grekis vn to distruccioun
As men in these old gestis rede
My hert quod on is on more in drede
I trowe som men of Armys be þer In̄
That shape hem this cete for to wyn
It wer͗e right good þat al such þingis wer͗e knowe
Anothir rownyd to his felowe lowe
And seid he lyd for it was rathir lik
An Apparence made be som magik
As Iogelowris pleyin at these Festis grete
Of Sondry thoghtis thus þey Iangil and tret
As lewd pepil demyn comynly
Of thingis that ben made more subtilly
That they con in her boundis comp̉rehend
The demyn gladly to the badder end
And som of hem vondryn on the myrrour͗e
That born was vp in to the mastir tour͗e
Howe men myght in hit such thingis se
Anothir answerd and seid it myght wel be
Naturelly be composisciounz
Of Angellis and of sly reflexionz
And seid that in Rome was such one
The spak of Alcen And of vitelon̄
And of Aristotil þat vritith in her lyuiz
Of queynt myrours and prospecsatiuiz
As knowe they þat haue her bokis herd
And othir folk haue vondrit on þe swerd
That wold ꝑperissh thorowe euery thing
And fil in spech of Thelophus þe kyng
And of Achilles for his queynt spere
For he coud with hit both hele ⁊and dere
Right in such wise as men may with the swerd
Of wich right nowe yee haue ȝour͗e self herd
They spekyn of sondry harding of metaill
And spekyn of medecyns there with al
And howe ⁊and whan it shuld hard it be
Wich vn knowe Algate is vnto me
Tho speke they of Canacees ryng
And seid that such a wondir þing
Of craft of ryngis herd þey neuir non
Saue that be Moyses and kyng Salomon̄
Hadde Amaner connyng of such an Art
Thus seyn the pepil and drewyn apart
But netherles som seid þat it was
Wondir for to make of fern glas
And ȝit is glas nat like Asshen of fern
But for they haue knowe it so fern
Therfor sesith her Iangelyng and her wondi
As sore wondryn som on cause of thundir
On eb on flode on gossomyr and on myst
And on al thing til that the cause is wist
Thus Iangelyn they and Demyn ⁊and Deuise
Til that the kyng gan from his bord Arise
Phebus hath laft the Angill Mereddional
And ȝit assendid was the best riall
The gentil lyoun with hiz Aldryan
When that thiz tartir kyng Cambuscan
Rose fro hiz bord there he sat ful hiȝe
Be forn hym goith the lowd mynstralsy
Til that he cam to his Chambir of parementz
There as there sownyn Dyuers Instrumentiz
That it is like an hauyn for to here
Nowe Dawnsyn lusty venus Childryn Dere
For in the Fissh her lady sat ful hiȝe
And lokith on hem with a frendly ye
This nobil kyng is set oppon his trone
This straunge thing is set to hym ful sone
And on the Daunce he goith with Canace
Ther͗e is the reuel and the Iolite
That is nat abil a Dul man to Deuise
He must knowe loue and his seruise
And be a festlich man as frossh az may
That shul ȝewe deuise such aray
Who coud ȝewe tellyn the forym of Daunsiz
So vncowth and so fressh contenᵃaunsiz
And therto such subtil lokenigiz
For drede of Ielowse of mennys preysuigiz
No man but Lawncelot and he is dede
Therfor I pas ouir of al this lusty hede
I sey no more but in this Iolynezz
I lete hem tyl men to the Soper hem Drez
The Steward bid Spisiz for to hy
And eke the wynd in al thiz melody
The vssherz and the Squyers ben goon
The Spycis and þe wyne is comyn Anon
They ete and drynk and when this was at end
Vn to the tempil as reson was þey wend
The seruice do they solempnly þat Day
What nedith it to reherce her a ray
Ech man woot wele that a kyngis fest
Hath plente to the most and the lest
And deyntees mo than be in my knowynge
And aftir Seper goith this nobil kyng
To se his hors of bras with al the route
Of lordis and of ladys hym About
Such wondring was there of þis horz of bras
That sithen the grete sege of Troy was
Ther͗e as men oppon an hors Also
Ne was such a wondring as was þo
But fynally the kyng askith the knyght
The vertu of this coursour͗e and the myght
And preyd to tel hym his gouernᵃaunce
The hors a non gan to trip ⁊and daunce
When þat þis knyght leyd hond on his reyn
And seid sir there is no more to seyn
But yf yee list to rydn ony where
Yee must tril a pyn that stoudith in his eer͗e
Wich I shal tel ȝewe be twix vs to
Ȝee mot nempne hym to what plase also
Or to what contre yee list to ride
And when yee comyn ther͗e ȝe list abide
Bid hym discend and tril anothir pyn̄
For ther͗e in lyth the ffect of al the gyn̄
And he wol down dissend ⁊and do al ȝour͗e will
And in that plase he wol abide stil
They al the world the contrary swore
He shal nat thens be throwe ne bore
Or yf ȝewe list bid hym thous goon
Trill this pyn and he wel wanyssh Anon
Out of the sighte of euery maner whit
And com̄ a ȝen be it day or nyght
When that ȝowe list to clepyn hym a ȝen
In such a gise as I shal to ȝewe seyn
Be twen me and ȝewe and þat ryght sone
Ride when ȝewe list ther͗e is no more to done
Enfourmyd when þe kyng was of þe knyght
And hath conseyuid in his wit a right
The maner and the forym of al this thing
Ful glad and blith was þis nobil kyng
Repeyryrng vn to his reuel as be forn
The bridill is vn to the tour͗e I born
And kept among his Iewellis lefe ⁊and dere
The hors vanysshid I note in what manere
Out of heer͗e sight yee gete no more of me
But thus I lete in lust and Iolite
This Cambuskan his lordis festing
Til wel the day be gan to spring
The norissh of degestionce þe slepe
Gan on hem wynk and bad hem take kepe
That much mete and labour͗e wol haue rest
And with agalping mowith hem al he kist
And seid it was tyme for to ly adown̄
For blode was in his Dominacioun
Cherisith blode naturys frend quod he
The þankyn hym galping be to be thre
And euery white gan drawe hym to his rest
As slepe hem bad þey toke it for þe best
Her dremes shul nat be told for me
Ful weer her hedis of fumocite
That causith dreme of wich þe is no charge
They slepyn til it was pryme large
The most part but it weer Canace
She was ful mesurabil as wommen be
For of her fadir had she take her leue
To go to rest son aftir it was eue
Her list nat apallid for to b
Sue on the morowe vn festlich for to se
And slept her first slepe and a wook
For such ioy she in her mirrour͗e toke
Both of her queynt ryng and her myrrour͗e
That twenty tyme she chaungid her coloure
And in her slepe for her impressioun
Of her myrrour͗e she had avisioun̄
Wherfor or the son gan vp glide
She clepid vp her mastrese her be side
And seid that her list forto a rise
These old wommen þat ben gladly wise
As her mastrese answerd her anon̄
And seid madame wheþir wol yee goon̄
Thus erly for the folk ben al in rest
I wol quod she arise for me lest
No lengir but walkyn about
Her wastes clepith wommen a gret rout
And vp they reysen aten or twelue
Vp risith fressh canace her selue
As rody and bright as þe yong Son̄
That in the ram is ten degreis I ron̄
No hiȝer was she when she redy was
And forth she walkith esely apase
Arayd aftir the lusty seson sote
Lightly for to pley and walkyn on foot
Not but· B· or vi of her meyne
And in a trench for·m apark goith she
The wapour wich fro the erth glode
Makith the son to seme rody ⁊and brode
But nathiulese it was so feir of sight
That it made al her hertis for to lite
What for the seson̄ and the morwenynge
And for the fowlis that she herd sing
For right anon she wist what þey ment
Right by her song and knewe al her entent
The knot why þat euery tale is told
If it be taryd til that lust be cold
Of hem þat haue it after herknyd aftir ȝor
The sauour͗e passith euir lengir the more
For fulsumnese of porlexite
And by this same reson thm kith me
I shuld vn to the knot condiscend
And makyn of her walkyng son an end
Amyd a tree for drye as white as chalk
As Canace was pleying in her walk
There sat a Fawcon ouir her hede ful hiȝe
That with apetouse vois so gan to cry
That al the wood resownyd of her cry
And betyn had her self so petously
With both her wyngis til the rede blode
Ran enlong the tre as she stode
And euir in on she cryd al wey ⁊and shrite
And with hir bek her self so she pryte
That there was tigre ne no cruel best
That dwellith in wood or in forest
That wold haue wept if he wepe cowith
For sorowe of here she shrite al wey so lowith
For ther͗e was neuir ȝit man on lyue
Yf that I cowd a Fawcon wel discryue
That herd of such a nothir of feirnese
As wele of plumage as of gentilese
Of shap̄p̄ of al that myght I rekenyd be
A Faucon peregryn than semyd she
Of frend land and euir as she stode
She swownyd newe and newe for lak of blode
Til wel nyȝe is she fallyn from þe tre
This feir kyngis doghter Canace
That on her fyngir bare þe queynt ryng
Thorowe wich she vndirstode wele euery þing
That ony foule may in his ledyn seyn
And coud answere in his ledyn ageyn
She hath vndirstond what þis Faucon seide
And wel nyȝe for the rowith she dey
And to the tre she goithful hastely
And on this Fawcon lokith ful petously
And held her lap abrode for wele she wist
The Fawcon must fal from þe twist
When þat it swownyth next for lak of blode
Along while to wayte there she stode
Til atte last she spak in þis manere
Vn to the hawke as yee shul aftir here
What is the case yf it be for to tel
That yee be in this furial peyn of hel
Quod Canace vn to this hawke Aboue
Is it for sorwe of deth or los of loue
For as I trowe these bens þe cawsis to
That cawsith most agentil hert woo
Of othir harm it redith nat to speke
For thogh your͗e self oppon ȝour͗e self wold wreke
Wich preuith wele þat othire Ire or drede
Must be encheson of ȝeur͗e cruel Dede
Syn that I se non othir white ȝewe chase
For loue of God so do ȝeur͗e self grace
Or what may be ȝeur͗e help for westrne est
Saw I neuir or nowe brid ne best
That ferdi with hym self so petously
Ȝee sle me with ȝeur͗e sorowe verrely
I haue of ȝewe so grete compassioun̄
For Goddis loue com fro þe tre A down̄
And as I am a kyngis doghter trewe
Yf þat I verrely the cawsis knewe
Of ȝeur͗e disese yf it lay in my myght
I wold a mend it or it were nyght
As wissyly help me grete God of kynd
And erbis shal I right I nowe fynd
To hele with yeur͗e hurtis hastely
Tho shrite this Fawcon more petously
Than euir she did and fil to ground A non̄
And lyth in swown as dede as ony Foon
Tyl Canace hath her in hir lap I take
Vn to the tyme she gan out of her swown awake
And aftir þat she out of swown gan breid
Right in her hawkis leid thus she seid
That pete rennyth son̄ in gentil hert
Feling his symylitude in peynys Smert
Is prouid al day as men may se
As wel be werk as by autoryte
For gentil hert kyth gentilnes
I se wele that yee haue of my distres
Compassyon̄ my feir͗e gentil Canace
Of verry wommanly benignite
That nature in yeur͗e principlis haue I set
But for no hope for to fare the bet
But for to obey to ȝeur͗e hert fre
And for to make othir be ware be me
As by the welp chastid is þe lyoun
Right for that cause and þat conclusioun̄
Whilis that I haue a leyser and a spase
My harm I wol confez or I pase
And euir whilis þe ton her Sorowe told
The tothir wept as she to wat̉er wold
Til þat þe Fawkon bad her be stil
And with a sik thus seid she her will
Ther͗e I was bred alas that Day
And fostrid in aroch of marbil gray
So tendirly þat no thing eylid me
Ine wist what was aduercite
Til I coude fly ful hy vnder þe sky
Tho dwellid a Tarcelet me fast by
That semed wel of al gentilnes
Al were he ful of treson̄ and falsnes
That is vrappid vndir humbil cherre
And vndir hewe of trowith in such manere
Vndir plesaunce and vndir besy peyn
That no white cold a went he coud feyn
So depe in greyn he dyid his colowirs
Right as a serpent hidith hym vndir flowrys
Til he may se his tyme for to bite
Right so this God of loue this I pocrite
Doith so his sermons and his obeysaunces
And kepith in semblaunce al his obsuruᵃaunces
That sownyth vn to gentilnes of loue
As in a Tombe is al the feir aboue
And vndir is the cors such as yee woot
Such was this Ipocrite both cold ⁊and hote
And in this wise he ʆseruid his entent
That saue þe fend non wist what he ment
Til he so long had wept ⁊andcompleynyd
And many a ȝeer his ʆseruice vn to me feynyd
Til that my hert to petouse and to nyce
Al Innocent of his crownyd malice
For ferd of his deth as thought me
Oppon his othis and his suerte
Graunt hym loue oppon þis condicioun
That eủere mo myn honour and renoun
Were sauid both pryuey and apte
This is to sey that aftir his desert
I ȝaf hym al my hert ⁊and al my þoght
God woot and he and othir wise noght
And toke his hert in chong of myn for ay
But soth is seid goon sith is many a day
A trewe white and a thefe þinkith nat one
And when he sy the thing so fer agoon̄
That I graunt hym fully my loue
In such agise as I haue seid aboue
And ȝeue hym my trewe hert as fre
As he swore heȝaf his hert to me
Anon þis tigir ful of dubbilnese
Fil on his kneis with so grete hummlus
With hiȝe reuerence as by his chere
So like a gentil louer in manere
So rauisshid as it semed for Ioy
That neuir Iason ne Paris of Troy
Iason certis ne non othir man
Syn Lameth was þat Althirfirst be gan̄
To louyn to as wrytyn folk be forn̄
Ne neuir sith the first man was born
Ne coud man be twenty þowsand part
Countirfete the Sophymes of his Art
Ne weer worthy to vnbokil his galich
There dubbilnesse or Feynyng shuld aproch
Ne so thank a white as he did me
His maner was an heuyn for to see
To ony womman weer she neuir so wise
So poyntid he his chere at poynt deuise
As wele his wordis as his contenᵃaunce
And so I louid hym for his obeysaunce
And for the trowith I demed in his hert
That yf so were that ony thing hym smert
Al were it neuir so lite and I it wist
Me thought I herd deth at my hert twist
And shortly so ferforth this thing went
That my will was his willis Instrument
This is to sey my wil obeyid his wil
In al thing aftir that reson̄ fil
Keping the bondis of my worship eủere
Ne neuir had I thing so lefe ne leuir
As hym God woot ne neuir shal no mo
This lastid leng̉er than a ȝeer or to
That I supposid of hym no þing but good
But fynally thus atte last it stode
That fortune wold þat he must twyn̄
Out of þat plase wich I was In̄
Where me weer woo it is no questioun̄
I can nat make of it Discripcioun
For o thing dare I tel boldely
I knowe what þe peyn of deth is there by
Such harm I met that he mygh me lene
So on a day of me he toke his leue
So sorowfully eke þat I went verrely
That he had felt as much sorowe as I
When that I herd hym Speke ⁊and saw his hewe
But nether lese I thoughte he was so trewe
And eke that he repeir shuld ageyn
With in alitil while soth to seyn̄
And reson̄ wold eke þat he must go
For his honour͗e as oft fallith so
That I made vertu of necessite
And toke it wele syn that it must be
As I best myght I hid from hym my sorowe
And toke hym be þe hond Seynt Iohn̄ to borowe
And I seid thus lo I am ȝewris al
Both such as I haue be to ȝewe and shal
What he answerd nedith not to reherce
Who can sey bet þan he þat can do werse
When he hath al seid þan hath he done
Therfor behouith hym along spone
That shal ete with a fend þus herd I sey
So atte last he must forth his wey
And forth he fleith til he com there hym list
When it cam hym to purpose for to rest
I trowe he had the tixt in mynd
That al thing repayrith to his kynd
Gladith hym self thus seyn men as I gese
Men love of propir kynd newefangilnese
As briddis don that men in cagis fede
For they thowe myght al day of hem take hede
And strawe her cage feir and soft as silk
And ȝyue hym sugir hony brede ⁊and mylk
Ȝit right anon as son as his dor is vp
He with his feet wol spurn down his cupp
And to the wood he wol and wormys ete
So newefangil be they of her mete
And loue nouelryis of propir kynde
No gentilnes of blode may hym bynd
So ferd this Tarcellet allas þat day
Thogh he were gentil born fressh ⁊and gay
And good for to see humbil and free
He sawe oppon atyme akyte flee
And sodynly he lovid þis kyte so
That al his love was clene fro me go
And hath his trowith falsid in þis wise
Thus hath þe kyte my loue in her ʆservise
As I am lorn with out remedy
And with þat word þis Fawcon gan to cry
And swownyd eft in Canaceis harm̄
Grete was the sorowe for þe hawkis harm̄
That Canace and al her wommen made
They nust howe þey myght þe Fawcon glade
But Canace home berith her in her lap
And softly in plasterys gan her wrap
Ther as she with her bek had hurt her selve
Nowe can nat Canace but herbis delve
Out of the ground ⁊and make salues newe
Of herbis preciouse and fyne of hewe
To hele with the hewke fro day to nyght
She doith hir besines and al her myght
And by her beddis hede she made a mewe
And koueryd it with velewettis newe
In sign of trowith that is in vommen sene
And al with out the mewe I peyntid grene
In wich wer͗e peyntid al þese fals fowlis
As bene þese tidissis tarceletttis ⁊and owlis
Right for dispite were peyntid her beside
Pyis on hem for to Gawr͗e and chide
Thus lete I Canace her hawke kepin
I wol as nowe no more speke of her Ryng
Til it com eft to purpose for to seyn
Howe þat þis fawcon gate her loue ageyn
Repentᵃunt as þe story tellith vs
By mediacioun of Kambalus
The kyngis son of wich I ȝowe told
But hens forth I wol proces hold
To spekyn of aventurys ⁊and of batteƚƚ
That ȝit was neuir herd so grete merueƚƚ
First wol I tel ȝewe of Cambuscan
That in his tyme many a Cete wan
And aftir wol I speke of Algarsyfe
Howe þat he wan Teodera to his wyfe
For whom ful oft in grete ꝑperel he was
Ne had he be holpyn by þe hors of bras
And aftir wol I speke of Camballo
That faght in listis with bretheren to
For Canace or þat he myght her wyn
And there I left I wol aȝen be gyn
O Appollo whirlith vp his chare so hyȝe
Thil þat God mercurious house þe sliȝe
¶ Squyers tale for Chawser made no more
And here begynnyth þe marchᵃunte his prolog
Weping ⁊and weylyng care and othir sorowyng
I knowe I nowȝe both on evyn ⁊and eke on morowe
Quod the marchᵃunte and so doith othir mo
That weddid be I trowe that it be so
For wele I woot it farith so be me
I have a wyfe þe worst þat may be
For thogh the Fend cowplid to her were
She wol hym ovir mach I dare wele swere
What shuld I ȝewe reherce in special
Her hiȝe malice she is a shrewe at al
Ther̉e is along and a large difference
Be twix Grisildis grete pacienc
And of my wyfe the passing cruelte
Were I vn bound also mot I the
As wold I nevir eft com in the snare
We weddit men lyvyn in sorowe ⁊and care
Asay who so wol and he shal fynd
That I say soth be seynt Thomas of ynd
As for the more part I sey nat al
God sheld that it shuld so be fal
A good Sir hoost I have I weddit be
These monthes to and no more parde
And ȝit I trowe he hath al his lyfe
Wyflese be thogh þat men wold him ryve
In to the hert ne coud in no maner where
Tel so much sorowe as I nowe here
Coude tel of my vyvis cursidnes
Nowe quod our̉e hoost Marchᵃunte so God ȝewe bles
Syn yee so mykil coude of þat art
Ful hertly I prey ȝewe tel vs part
Gladly quod he but of myn own sore
For sory hert I tel may no more

l.hi: And here begynnyth the Marchᵃunte his tale

div.l: Whylom was dwellyng in lumbarde
A worthy knyght þat born was at pave
In wich he lyvid in grete prosperite
And xl ȝeer a wyfles man was he

That thilke tyme of Pauyk was Countesse
He sholde it take and shewe hir this matere
Bisekynge hir to doon hir bisynesse
This child to fostre in alle gentilesse
And whos child that it was he bad hir hyde
From euery wight for aught that may bityde
The Sergeant goth and hath fulfild this thyng
But to this Markys now retourne we
For now goth he ful faste ymagynyng
If by his wyues cheere he myghte se
Or by hir word aperceyue that she
Were chaunged but he neuere hir koude fynde
But euere in oon ylike sad and kynde
As glad as humble as busy in seruyse
And eek in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in euery maner wise
Ne of hir doghter noght a word spak she
Noon accident for noon aduersitee
Was seyn in hir ne neuere hir doghter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game
Incipit pars quarta
IN this estat ther passed ben 4 yeer
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue child she bar by this Walter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contree merye
Was for this child and god they thanke and herye
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Departed of his Norice on a day
This Markys caughte yet another lest
To tempte his wyf yet ofter if he may
O nedelees was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wyf quod this Markys ye han herd er this
My peple sikly berth this mariage
And namely sith my sone yborn is
Now is it worse than euere in al oure age
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myne erys comth the voys so smerte
That it wel neigh destroyed hath myn herte
Now sey they thus whan Walter is agon
Thanne shal the blood of Ianycle succede
And been oure lord for oother haue we noon
Swiche wordes seith my peple out of drede
Wel oghte I of swich murmur taken hede
For certeinly I drede swich sentence
Though they nat pleyn speke in myn audience
I wolde lyue in pees if that I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed outrely
As I his suster serued by nyghte
Right so thenke I to serue hym priuely
This warne I yow that ye nat sodeynly
Out of your self for no wo sholde outraye
Beth pacient and ther of I yow praye
I haue quod she seyd thus and euere shal
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certeyn
But as yow list noght greueth me at al
Thogh that my doghter and my sone be sleyn
At youre comandement this is to seyn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first siknesse and after wo and peyne
Ye ben oure lord dooth with your owene thyng
Right as yow list axeth no reed of me
For as I lefte at hom al my clothyng
Whan I first cam to yow right so quod she
Lefte I my wyl and al my libertee
And took youre clothyng wher fore I yow preye
Dooth your plesance I wol youre lust obeye
And certes if I hadde prescience
Youre wyl to knowe er ye your lust me tolde
I wolde it doon with outen necligence
But now I woot youre lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesance ferm and stable I holde
For wiste I that my deeth wolde doon yow ese
Right gladly wolde I dyen yow to plese
Deeth may nat make no comparisoun
Vn to youre loue and whan this Markys say
The constance of his wyf he caste adoun
Hise eyen two and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with drery contenance
But to his herte it was ful gret plesance
This vggly XXgeant in the same wyse
That he hir doghter caughte right so he
Or worse if men worse kan deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beautee
And euere in oon so pacient was she
That she no cheere made of heuynesse
But kiste hir sone and after gan it blesse
Saue this she prayde hym that if he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to sighte
Fro foweles and fro bestes hem to saue
But she noon answere of hym myghte haue
He wente his wey as hym no thyng roghte
But to Boloigne he tendrely it broghte
This Markys wondreth euer lenger the moore
Vp on hir pacience and if that he
Ne hadde soothly knowen ther bifoore
That perfitly hir children loued she
He wolde haue wend that of som subtiltee
And of malice or of cruel corage
That she hadde suffred this with sad visage
But wel he knew that next hym self certayn
She loued hir children best in euery wise
But now of wommen wolde I asken fayn
If thise assayes myghte nat suffise
What koude a sturdy housbond moore deuyse
To proue hir wifhod and hir stedfastnesse
And he contynuynge euere in sturdynesse
But ther ben folk of swich condicioun
That whan they haue a certeyn purpos take
And so wilful suche assayes to make
They kan nat stynte of hir entencioun
But right as they were bounden to that stake
They wol nat of that firste purpos slake
Right so this Markys fulliche hath purposed
To tempte his wyf as he was first disposed
He wayteth if by word or contenance
That she to hym was chaunged of corage
But neuere koude he fynde variance
She was ay oon in herte and in visage
And ay the ferther that she was of age
The moore trewe if that it were possible
She was to hym in loue and moore penyble
For which it semed thus that of hem two
Ther nas but o wyl for as Walter leste
The same lust was hir plesance also
And god be thanked al fyl for the beste
She shewed wel for no worldly vnreste
A wif as of hir self no thyng ne sholde
Wille in effect but as hir housbond wolde
The sclaundre of Walter ofte and wyde spradde
That of a cruel herte he wikkedly
For he a poure womman wedded hadde
Hath mordred bothe his children pryuely
Swich murmur was among hem comunly
No wonder is for to the peples ere
Ther cam no word but that they mordred were
For which wher as his peple ther bifore
Hadde loued hym wel the sclaundre of his diffame
Made hem that they hym hated therfore
To ben a mordrer is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stente
To tempte his wyf was set al his entente
Whan that this doghter xij yer was of age
He to the court of Rome in subtil wise
Enformed of his wil sente his message
Comaundynge hem swiche bulles to deuyse
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
In this maner and in this same gyse
How that the pope as for his peples reste
Bad hym to wedde another if hym leste
I seye he bad they sholde contrefete
The popes bulles makyng mencioun
That he hath leue his firste wyf to lete
As by the popes dispensacioun
To stynte rancour and dissencioun
Bitwix his peple and hym thus seyde the bulle
The which they han publissed at the fulle
The rude peple as it no wonder is
Wenden ful wel that it hadde ben right so
But whan thise tidynges cam to Grisildis
I deme that hir herte was ful wo
But she ylike sad for euere mo
Disposed was this humble creature
Thaduersitee of Fortune al tendure
Abidynge euere his lust and his plesance
To whom that she was yeuen herte and al
As to hir verray worldly suffisance
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markys writen hath in special
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of Pavyk which that hadde tho
Wedded his suster prayde he specially
To bryngen hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
With all his hert ful affectuously
But o thyng he hym prayde outrely
With all his herte ful affectuously
That he to no wight thgh men wolde enquere
Sholde nat tellen whos children that they were
But seye the mayden sholde ywedded be
Vn to the Markys of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was prayd so dide he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
And forth he rod / ful fast a noon
Toward Saluce and lordes many oon
Toward Saluce / this Mayde for to gyde
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir bisyde
Arrayed was toward hir mariage
This fresshe mayde ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which that seuen yeer was of age
Arrayed eek ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad cheere
Toward Saluces shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day they ryden in hir wey
This Markys yet his wif to tempte moore
To the outreste preue of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seyd hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I hadde ynogh plesance
To han yow to my wyf for your goodnesse
As for youre trouthe and for your obeysance
Noght for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sondry wyse
I may nat do as euery Plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eek the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And trewely thus muche I wol yow seye
My newe wif is comynge by the weye
Be strong of herte and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Tak it agayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous quod he
No man may alwey han prosperitee
With euene herte I rede yow tendure
The strook of Fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway
How that bitwixen youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparisoun it is no nay
I ne heeld me neuere digne in no manere
To be your wyf no ; ne youre chambrere
And in this hous ther ye me lady made
The heighe god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuere heeld me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And euere shal whil that my lyf may dure
Abouen euery worldly creature
That ye so longe of youre benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryelde it yow ther is namoore to seye
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyues ende
Ther I was fostred of a child ful smal
Til I be deed my lyf ther wol I lede
A wydewe clene in body herte and al
For sith I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyf it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbond or to make
And of youre newe wyf god of his grace
So graunte yow wele and prosperitee
For I wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For sith it liketh yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon I wol goon whan yow leste
But ther as ye me profre swich dowaire
As I first broghte it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thyng faire
The whiche to me were hard now for to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But sooth is seyd algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect it proued is on me
Loue is noght old as whan that it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersitee
To dyen in this cas it shal nat be
That euere in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lord ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me strepe out of my poure wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broghte I noght ellis out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn my clothyng I restore
And eek my weddyng ryng for euere moore
The remenant of your Iewels redy be
Inwith your chambre dar I saufly sayn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked moot I turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklees out of your palays wente
Ye koude nat doon so dishoneste a thyng
That thilke wombe in which youre children leye
Sholde biforn the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wher fore I yow preye
Lat me nat lyk a worm go by the weye
Remembre yow myn owene lord so deere
I was youre wyf thogh I vnworthy weere
Wher fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I broghte and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wont to were
That I ther with may wrye the wombe of here
That was youre wyf and here I take my leeue
Of yow myn owene lord lest I yow greeue
The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnnethes thilke word he spak
But wente his wey for routhe and for pitee
Biforn the folk hir seluen strepeth shee
And in hir smok with heued and feet al bare
Toward hir fader hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepynge in hir weye
And Fortune ay they cursen as they goon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spak she noon
Hir fader that this tidynge herde anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to been a lyues creature
For out of doute this olde poure man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euere he demed sith that it bigan
That whan the lord fulfild hadde his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his estat so lowe for talighte
And voyden hir as soone as euere he myghte
Agayns his doghter hastiliche goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myghte be
He couered hire ful sorwefully wepynge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse
As clerkes whan hem lest konne wel endite
Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wommen kan ne kan be half so trewe
As wommen been but it be falle of newe
¶ . Quinta pars .
Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come
Of which the fame vp sprong to moore and lesse
And to the peples erys alle and some
Was kouth eek that a newe Markisesse
He with hym broghte in swich pomp and richesse
That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently and wysly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
Here may ye se the peple how newe
For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
And changeable be right as the mane
Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To han a newe lady of hir town
Namoore of this make I now mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the feste was apertinent
Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man aparceyueth
But ay they wondren what she myghte be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koude swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostred in hir norissynge
Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude nat aduersitee endure
As koude a poure fostred creature
And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad cheere and no malice at al
And he so ofte had doon to hir offence
And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
With pacience Grisild he quiteth
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
Mankynde which that he wroght
As wel as euere womman was assayed
In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wyf that oother feithfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
And nat to sleen my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
O which a pitous thyng it was to se
O such a pitous thing it was to see
Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
The children from hir arm they gonne arace
O many a teer o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
With a coroune of many a riche stoon
Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
And ther she was honured as hir oghte
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and womman dooth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
This feste was and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage
Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
And richely his doghter maried he
Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
His sone succedeth in his heritage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eek his mariage
Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is nat so strong it is no nay
As it hath been in olde tymes yore
And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
For it were inpor table thogh they wolde
But for that euery wight in his degree
Sholde be constant in aduersitee
As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
For sith a womman was so pacient
Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
He preueth folk al day it is no drede
And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
Er we were born knew al oure freletee
And for oure beste is al his gouernance
Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a town Grisildis thre or two
For if that they were put to swiche assayes
The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
For which heere for the wyues loue of Bathe
Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene
In heigh maistrie or ellis were it scathe
I wol with lusty herte fressh and grene
Seye yow a song to glade yow I wene
And lat vs stynte of ernestful matere
Herkneth my song that seith in this manere

l.hi: Here is ended the tale of the clerk of Oxenford

div.l: Grisild is dede and eke her pacience
And both attonys berird in Itaile
For wich I cry in opyn audience
No weddid man so hardy be toasaile
His vivis pacience in trust to fynd ¶
Grisildis for in certen he shal faile
O nobil vives ful of prudence
Let non humilite your tongis nayle
Ne let no clerk have cause or dilligence
To vrite of ȝowe a story or such a mervaile
As of Grisild pacient and kynd
Lest Chyvache ȝowe swalowe in Itaile
Folowith eke that holdith in scilence
But eủer answering atte countir taile
Be not a daffid for your Innocentt
But shortly take on ȝewe þe governaile
Enpoyntith wele this lesson in your mynd
For comyn profite seith it may a vaile
Yee Archevivis stond yee at diffence
Syn yee be strong as is agrete camaile
Ne suffir nat that men do ȝewe offence
But sklendir vivis as febil in batail
Beth egr and tegr fynde is fer in ynd
Ay clapping as a mil I ȝewe counsaile
Ne dredith hem not ne do hem no reverence
For thogh thy husbond I Armyd be in maile
Thy wordis of thi crabbid eloquence
Shal perissh his brest and eke his auentaile
In Ielowsy I rede eke that thowe hym bynd
And þowe shal make hym couch as a quaile
Yf thowe be feir þer folk be in presence
Shewe thowe þy visage and thyn apꝑparayle
Yf þowe be foule be fre of þy dispence
To gete the Frendis ay do þy travaile
Be ay of cher as lighte as lefe on lynd
And let hym care wepe wring ⁊and waile
This worthy Clerk when endid was his tale
Our hoost seid and swore be Goddis bonys
Me wer levir than abarel of ale
My wyfe had herd this legend onys
This is agentil tale for the nonys
As to my pʳpose wist yee my wil . //
But þing þᵗat wol nat be let it be stil
¶ Here endith the tale of þe Clerk of Oxinford
¶ Here begynnyth the Franklen his prolog
These old gentil bretonns in her dayis
Of divers Autours madyn her̉e layis
Rymyng fyrst in her breton̄ tong
Such layis with her̉e instrumentis they song
Or ellis reddyn hem for her plesaunce
And on̄ of hem have I in remembraunce
Wich I shal sey with as good wil as I can̄
But sirris be cause I am aborel man̄
At my be gynnyng first I ȝewe beseche
Have me excusid of my rude spech
I lernyd nevir retris in certeyn̄
Thing that I speke must be al bare ⁊and pleyn̄
I slept nevir in the mount of ꝑparvanso
Ne lernyd Marcus Tullius Sichero
Colowris knewe I non̄ without drede
But such colowris as growen̄ in the mede
Or ellis such as men dien ⁊and peynt
Colouris of retrik ben̄ ful queynt
My sperit felith not such mater̉e
But and yee lift my tale shul yee her̉e
¶ Here endith he his prologg
And here begynnyth the Franklen his tale
In Amorik þat callid is breteyn̄
Þer̉e was aknyght that lovid ⁊and did his peyn̄
To serve alady in his best wise
And many alabour̉e and many agᵉrete emprise
He for his lady vroght or she weer̉e won̄
For she on of the feyrest was vndir son̄
And eke ther̉e to I comyn̄ of so hiȝe kynrede
That wel vnneth durst this knyght for drede
Tel her̉e his woo or peyn or his distres
But atte last she for his worthines
And namly for his meke obeysaunce
Hath such apete caght of his penaunce
That she pryvyly fil of his acord
To take hym for her̉e husbond ⁊and her̉e lord
Of such lordschipp̄e as men have of her̉e vivis
And for to lede in the more bles her lyvis
Of his fre wil he swore as he was trewe knygh
That nevir in al his lyfe be day ne nyght
Ne shuld of hym take the mastre
Ageyns her̉e wil ne kyith her̉ e Ielowse
But her̉e obey and folowe her̉e wil in al
As ony lover to his lady shal
Save only the name of soverente
That wold he have for shame of his degre
She thankith hym of his humbilnes
She seid sir of yeur̉e getilnes
Yee profir̉e me to have so large areyn̄
Now wold to God þat nevir be twix vs tweyn̄
As in my gilt wer̉e othir̉e werr̉e or stryfe
Sir I wol be yeur̉e humbil trewe wyfe
Have her̉e my trowith til my hert brest
This ben̄ they boith in quyete and in rest
For o thyng sirris savly dare I sey
That Frendis everych othir̉e must obey
Yf that they wol hold company
When mastry is com̄ to God of love anon̄
Betith her̉e wyngis and fare wele he is goon̄
Love is athing as ony thing free
For vommen of kynd disiryn liberte
And nat to be constreynyd as a thral
And so do men yf I for soth tel shal
Look who so is most pacient in love
He is at his avauntage al above
Pacience is an hiȝe vertu certeyn̄
For it venquissh as clerkis seyn̄
Thingis that rigour̉e nevir shul ateyn̄
For every word men may nat chide or pleyn̄
Lernyth to suffir̉e or ellis so mot I goon̄
Yee shul it lern̄ whethir̉e yee wol or non̄
For in this world certen no white is
That he ne doith or seyith som tyme amys
Ire siknes or constillacioun̄
Wyn̄ woo or chaungung of complexioun̄
Causith ful oft to do it mys or spekyn
On every vrong aman̄ may nat be a vrokyn̄
Aftir the tyme must be termꝑperaunce
To every white that can of governᵃaıı̄unce
And ther for hath this wise worthy knyght
To lyve in her̉e sufferaunce her̉e be hight
And she to hym ful wisely gan swer̉e
That nevir defaut shuld be in her̉e
Her̉e men may se in humbil wise acord
This hath she take her̉e ʆseruᵃante and her̉e lord
Servaunte in love and in mariage
Than was he boith in lordshipp̄e and in ʆservage
Servage nay but in lordship above
Sithen̄ he hath both his haly and his love
His lady certis and his wyfe also
The wich lawe and love acordith ther̉eto
And when̄ he was in this prosꝑperite
Home with his wyfe he goith to his contre
Not fer̉e fro padmeck his dwellyng was
Wher̉e as he lyvith in blis and in solas
Who coude tel it but he þat weddit had be
The Ioy the ese the prosperite
That is be twixe an husbond ⁊and his wyfe
Aȝeer̉e or more lastith this blesful lyfe
Thil that this knyght of wich I spak of thus
That of his kynrede was clepid Aruergagus
Shope hym to goon̄ and dwel aȝeer̉e or tweyn̄
In Englond that clepid was breteign̄
To seke in armys worship and honour̉e
For al his lust he set in such labour̉e
And dwellid ther̉e to ȝeer̉e the book seith þus
Nowe wol I stynt of Aruaragus
And speke I wol of Dorigene his wyfe
That lovid her̉e husbond as her̉e lyfe
For his absence wepith she and sikith
As don̄ þese good vivis when that hem likith
So murnyth wakith weylith fastith pleynyt
Desire of his presence so her distreynyth
That al this wyde world she set at noght
Her̉e Frendis that knewe her̉e they thoght
As comfort her̉e in al that evir they may
The p̉rechyn her̉e they tel her̉e nyght and day
That causles she sleith her̉e self alas
And eviry comport possibil in that cas
They do ther̉e to al her besines
Men may so long gravyn̄ in aston̄
Be proces as yee knowe everichon̄
Til som̄ fegur̉e ther̉e in printid bee
So long hath they comfortid til she
Reseyvid hath be hope and be rosonıı̄un
The emprenting of her̉e consolacioun̄
Thorowe wich her̉e grete sorowe gan to swage
She may nat al wey duryn̄ in such arage
And eke Arueragus in al this care
Hath sent her̉e lettirs of his wel fare
And þat he wold com hastely ageyn̄
Or ellis had this sorowe her̉e hert sleyn̄
Her̉e Frendis her̉e sorowis for to slake
Hath preyid her̉e for Goddis sake
To com̄ amd Rome in her̉e company
Awey to Dryve her̉e derk fanteȝie
And finally she grauntid þat request
For wele she sawe it was for þe best
Nowe stode ther̉e a Castel fast be the see
And þedir with her̉e Frendis walkith she
Her̉e to disport oppon̄ the bank only
Wher̉e she many shippis and bargis sy
Seyling her̉e cours wher̉e þat hem list to go
But ȝit was that aparcel of her̉e woo
For to her̉e self alas ful oft seid she
Is ther̉e no shipp so many as I see
Wol bring home my love þan wer̉e my hert
Al warisshid of my bitt̉er peynys smer
Anothir̉e tyme she wold sit and think
And castyn̄ her yȝen̄ down̄ward from þe brink
But when she sy the grisly Rokkis blake
For verry feer̉e she wold in her̉e hert quake
That on her̉e feet she myght nat sustene
Than̄ wold she sit down̄ oppon the grene
And pitously on the se the Rokkis be hold
And seith right thus with sighis cold
Etern̄ God that thorowe thy purveaunce
Ledist the world be certen governauce
In Idil as yee sey yee no thing make
But lord these grisly Rokkis blake
That semyn rathir̉e to foule confucioun̄
Of werk as to yeur̉e creacioun̄
Of such a ꝑparfite wise O good god so stabil
Why have yee uroght this work unresonabil
For be this work North South ne Est
Ther̉e is I fosterid man brid ne best
It doiIth no wit good to my wit but anoyith
Se yee nat lord howe man kynd it distroyith
An hundrit thowsand bodiIs of man kynd
Have rokkis sleyn̄ al thogh they be not In mynd
Syn̄ man kynd is so feir̉e part of thy werk
That thowe it made like to thyn̄ own̄ werk
Than semed that yee had don̄ grete charite
Toward man kynde howe may it þan be
That yee such menys make it to distroyen̄
Such menes doon no good but Anoyen̄
I woot that clerkis seyn̄ as hem list
Be Argumentis that al is for the Ibest
Thogh I ne can̄ the cawsis wele knowe
But þat God that made the wynd to blowe
As kepe my lord this is myn̄ conclucioun̄
To clerkis lete I al this disputacioun̄
But wold to God that al these rokkis blake
Weer̉e sonkyn̄ into hel for his sake
These Rokkis sle my hert for fer̉
This word she seid with many apetouse tere
Her̉e Frendis that sy it was no disport
To romen be the see but discomfort
And shapyn hem for to pley som wher̉e ellis
To ledyn her̉e be revers and be wellis
And in othir̉e plase dilectablis
They daunsyn̄ and pleyen̄ atte dise ⁊and atte tablis
So ond day al in the morowe tide
Un to agardyn̄ that was ther̉e be side
In wich that they had made her ordenᵃaunce
Of uitail and of al othir̉e purveaunce
They go and pley hem al the long Day
And this was in the sixt morowe of may
Wich may hath peyntid with her̉e soft showris
The gardeyn̄ ful of levis and of Flowris
And craft of mannys hond so coryously
Arayid hath this garden trewly
That nevir was ere was þer̉e gardyn of such prise
But yf it weer̉e the uerry paradise
The odour̉e of Flowris and the Fressh sight
Wold have made ony hert light
But yf it weer̉e for to grete siknes
Or to grete sorowe hold in distres
So ful it was of bewte with plesaunce
And aftir̉e dyner they go for to Daunce
And sing also save Doregen̄ alon̄
Wich made her̉e compleynt and her̉e mone
For she ne sawe nat hym̄ in the daunce goon̄goon̄ go
That was her̉e husbond and love also
But nethirlese she must her̉e tyme abide
And with good hope lete her sorowis slide
Oppon̄ this Daunce oppon̄oppon̄ among oþir̉e men̄
Daunsith a squyer̉e be forēn Dorregen̄
Tha fressh was and Iolyer of assay
As to my dome than̄ is the month of may
He singith daunsith passing ony othir̉e man̄
That is or was sith the world be gan̄
Ther with he was yf men shuld hym discrive
On of the best faring men on lyve
Ȝong strong vertewous and wise
And wel be lovid and hold in grete prise
And shortly yf I the soth tel shal
Un weting of this Dorrigen̄ at al
This lusty squyer servaunt to uenus
Wich that clepid was Aurilius
He lovid her best of ony creatur̉e
To ȝeer and more and was his aventur̉e
But nevir durst he tel her his grevᵃaunce
With out the cup drank he al his penᵃaunce
He was dispeyrid no thing durst he sey
Save in his songis som̄ dele wold he urey
This was in general compleynyng
He seid he lovid and belovid no thyng
Of such mater made he many layis
Songis compleyntis roundellis uraylis
Howe þat he durst nat his sorowe tel
But langing as afeir̉e doith in hell
And dy he must he seyd as did Ecco
For Narcrisus þat durst nat tel hes wo
In othir̉e wise than̄ yee her̉e me sey
Ne durst he nat his wo be urey
Save ꝑparaventur̉e at dauncis
Ther̉e ȝong folk kept her̉e observᵃauncis
Hit may wele ben̄ he lokid in her̉e fase
In such wise as men that axin grace
But no thing wist she of his entent
Nethirles it happid or they went
Be cause that he was her̉e Neyȝbour̉e
And was aman of worship ⁊and honour̉e
And had knowyn hym̄ tymes ȝore
They fillyn in spech and so morre ⁊and more
Un to his purpose drewe Aurlyliu
And when he sy his tyme he seid thus
Madame quod he be God þat þis woulde made
So that I wist I myght yeur̉e hert glade
I wold þat day that yeur̉e Arueragus
Went ovir the see that I Aurilius
Had goon̄ ther̉e I shuld nevir acom̄ aȝen̄
For wel I woot my service is in veyn̄
My guerdon̄ is but bresting of myn hert
Madame but ȝee rewe on my peyny smert
Her̉e at ȝeur̉e feet God wold I wer̉e I grave
I have as nowe no more leyser to sey
Have mercy swete or yee wol do me dey
She gan for to look oppon Aurilius
Is þis yeur̉e wil quod she and sey yee þus
Nevir ȝit quod she wist I what yee ment
Be IhūIhesu Criste omnipotent
Be þat God þat ȝave me soule ⁊and lyfe
Ne shal I nevir be untrewe wyfe
In word ne in work as fer̉e as I have wit
I wol be his to whom I am knyt
Take this for fynal answer̉e as of me
But aftir that in pley thus seid she
Aurily quod she be hiȝe God above
Ȝit wol I graunte for to be yeur̉e love
Syn I se ȝewe so petously compleyn̄
Loke what day Inglong is breteyn̄
Yee remeve al the Rokkis stōe be stone
That they ne let shippis for to goon̄
I sey when̄ yee have made this coost so clene
Of rokkis that ther̉e is non̄ I sene
Than wol I love ȝewe best of ony man̄
Have her̉e my trowith in al þat evir I can̄
For wele I woot that it shal nevir̉e be tide
Let such foly out of yeur̉e hert glide
When deynte shuld aman̄ have in his lyf
For to go love anothir̉e mannys wyfe
To have her̉e body when so þat hym likith
Aurⁱilius ful oft he sorowith and sikith
Is ther̉e non othir̉e grace on ȝewe quod he
No be that lord that hath I made me
Woo was Aurily when he this herd
And with a sorowful hert he þus answerd
Madame quod he this weer̉e an Impossibil
Than must I dy in soden deth horibil
And with that word he turnyth hym̄ Anon̄
Tho com her̉e othir̉e Frednis many on̄
And in the Aleyis romyd up and down̄
And no thing wistyn̄ of this conclucioun̄
And sodynly be gon to revel newe
Til the bright son̄ lest his hewe
For the oryent had rest þe son̄ her̉e light
This is as much to sey as it was nyght
And home they goon̄ in Ioy and in solas
Save only urecchid Aurilius Alas
He to his house is goon̄ with sorowful hert
He seith he may nat from his deth astert
He seith he felith his hert cold
Up to hevyn his hondis he gan hold
And on his kneis bar he set hym doun̄
And in Raveing seid his orysoun̄
For verry woo out of his wit he breyid
He nist what he spak but þus he seid
With petouse hert his pleynt he hath be gon̄
Unto the Goddis and þan to þe son̄
He seid Appollo God and governour̉e
Of every plant herbe tre and flour̉e
That ȝevist aftir thy declynacioun̄
To ech of hem his tym̄ and his sesoıı̄un
As thyn herborowe chaungith lowe ⁊and hiȝ
Therfor̉e my lord cast nowe yeur̉e ye
On wrecchid Aurili wich am but lorn̄
Lo lord my body hath my deth sworn̄
With out ony gilt but thy benignity
Oppon̄ my dedely hert have som̄ pete
But wele I woot Phebus yf yee list
Yee may me help save my lady best
Nowe uouch save that I may ȝewe devise
Howe that I may be holpyn and in what wise
Ȝeur̉e blesful sustir lucyna the shene
That of the see clyf Goddes is and Quene
Thogh Neptunus hath deite in the see
Ȝit Emꝑperes abovym hym is she
Ȝe knowe wele lord righe as her̉e desir̉e
Is to be quekenyd and liȝtenyd at ȝeur̉e fier̉e
For wich she folowith ȝeweful besely
Right so the see desirith naturelly
To folowe her̉e as she that is Goddes
Both in the see and Ryvers more ⁊and les
Wherfor lord Phebus this is my request
Do this myrakil or do my hert brest
That nowe next at þis apposicioun̄
When þat þe sign̄ shal be in the lyoun̄
As preyith her̉e so grete aflood to bring
That ten fadem̄ atte lest it oủer spring
The grettest Rok in Armorik breteyn̄
And let this flood endur̉e ȝeris tweyn̄
Than certis to my lady may I sey
Holdith yeur̉e hest þe Rokkis be a wey
Lord Phebus this myrakil do for me
Prey her̉e that she go no fastir̉e coursis þan ȝee
I sey thus prey ȝeur̉e sustir that she go
No faster̉e coursis þan ȝee these ȝeris to
Than shal she be at even ful alway
And spring flode last both nyȝt ⁊and da
And but yee uouch save in such maner̉e
To graunte me my soveren̄ lady dere
Prey her̉e to sink every Rok adoun̄
Into her̉e own̄ derk regioun̄
Undir the ground ther̉e Pluto dwellith In
Or nevir shal I my lady wyn̄
Thy tempil in delphos wol I seke
Lord Phebus se the teris on my cheke
And of my peyn have som̄ compassioun̄
And with þat word in swownyng he fil adoun̄
And long tyme he lay in a traunce
His brothir̉e wich knewe his penᵃaunce
Up caght hym and to bed hath him broght
Dispeyrid in this turment and in this thoght
Lete I this uoful creatur̉e ly
Chese he wethir̉e he wol lyve or dy
A rueragus with hele and honỏure
As he that was of Chivalry the Flour̉e
Is comyn̄ hom̄ and othir̉e worthy men̄
A blesful hert hath nowe Dorregen̄
That hast thy blesful husbond in thyn̄ armys
This fressh knyght this worthy man̄ of armys
That lovith the as his own̄ hert lyfe
No thing list hym to be Imagetyfe
What ony white had spoke whilis he was out
Tho to her̉e of love ther̉e of he had no dout
He nuld entend to such mater̉e
But daunsith Iustith and makith good cher̉e
And thus In Ioy and bles I lete hem dwel
And of the sik Aurilius wol I tel
In langour̉e and in turment furious
To ȝeer̉e and more lay this Aurilius
Or ony foot he myght on erth goon̄
Ne comfort in this tym̄ had honoủre
Save his brothir̉e wich was a Cler
That knewe al his woo and al his werk
For non̄ othir̉e Creatur̉e certeyn̄
Of this mater he durst no word seyn̄
Undir his brest he bare it more secre
Than evir did Phamphilus or Galathe
His brest was hool with outyn̄ for to seen̄
But in his hert hit was both rowȝe ⁊and kene
And wel ȝe knowe of surgeuir̉e
In surgery is perlous the cur̉e
But men myght touch the arowe or come þ̉ere by
His brothir̉e wepith ⁊and weylith pryvyly
Til atte last hum fil in remembraunce
That while he was in Orleaunce in Frᵃaunce
As ȝong Clerkis that ben̄ likorouse
To reden artis that ben̄ curious
Seken̄ in every halk and every hern̄
Perticuler̉e science for to lern̄
He him remembrit that oppon a day
In Orleaunce in a boke of study he say
Of magik naturel with his felawe
That was þat tym̄ a bacheler of lawe
Al wer̉e he ther̉e to lern̄ another̉e craft
Had pryvyly oppon his desk left
Wich Book spak much of þe opꝑperaciouns
And of many divers coniuraciouns
That longyn to the mone and such foly
As in our̉e dayis is nat worth afly
For holy Church seith and our̉e beleve
Ne suffrith non̄ illucioun̄ us to greve
And when this book was in his remembruᵃaunce
Anon̄ for Ioy his hert gan to daunce
And to him self he seid pryvyly
My brothir̉e warisshid shal be hastly
For I am sikir̉e ther̉e be sciencis
Be wich men makyn̄ diủers apparencis
Wich al these subtil tregetours pley

div.l: For oft at Festis have I herd sey
That Tregeturs with in an hal large
Hat semed com in watir and abarge
And in the hal rowyn̄ up and doun̄
Som tym̄ hath semed com in agrete lyoun̄
And some tyme flowris springing in amede
Som̄ tyme wyne and grapis white ⁊and rede
Som tym̄ a Castil of lyme and ston̄
And when hym likith voydith anon̄
Thus semed it to many a mannys sight
Nowe than conclude I thus yf that I myght
At Orleaunce som old felawe I fynd
That had the monys mancions in mynd
Or othir̉e magik naturel above
He shuld wele make my brothir̉e have his love
For wich apparence a Clerk may make
To mannys sight that al þese Rokkis blake
Of breten̄ weer̉e uordid everychon̄
And shippis be the brinkis comyn ⁊and goon̄
And in such fourm̄ endur̉e a week or to
Then̄ wer̉e my brothir̉e warisshid of his woo
Than must she nedis hold her̉e be hest
Or ellis he shal shame her̉e atte lest
What shuld I make alenger tale of this
Vnto his brothirs bed he comyn̄ is
And such comfort he ȝaf hym for to goon̄
To Orleaunce that he vp stert anon̄
And on his wey onward is he fare
In hope to be lissid of his care
When they wer̉e com al most to þat cete
But yf it wer̉e to furlongis or thre
A yong Clerk romyng be hym self þey met
Wich that in latyn thristelich hem gret
And after he seid a wondir thing
He told hem for what was her̉e comyng
This Breton Clerk hym axid of felawi
The wich he had knowyn̄ in old dayis
And he answerd hym that they dede wer̉e
For wich he uept ful many ater̉e
Doun̄ of his hors Aurilius light anon̄
And with this Magicien forth he gan̄ goon̄
Home to his house and made hym wele at ese
Hym lakkid no uitaile that myght hym plese
So wel arayid hous as ther̉e was on̄
Aurilius in his lyfe sawe nevir non̄
He shewid hym or þat he went to soꝑper
Forestis parkis ful of wild dere
Ther̉e sawe he hertis with her̉e hornys hiȝe
The grettest þat evir he sy with ye
He sy of hem an hundrit sleyn with houndis
And som̄ with arowis blede ⁊and bitt̉er uoundis
He sy when̄ uoydid wer̉e these wild der̉e
The Fawcons oppon̄ a feir̉e rever̉e
That with her̉e hawkis gan þe heyrin sleyn̄
Tho sy he knyghtis Iusting in apleyn̄
And aftir this he did hym such plesaunce
That he hym shewid his lady in a daunce
In wich hym self daunsid as hym thoght
And when this Mastir had þis magik uroght
Sy it was tyme and clappid his hondis to
And fare wele al our̉e rebel was ago
And remevid he nevir̉e out of his house
Whilis they sy al this mervelous
But in his stody ther̉e as his bokis be
They sittyn stil al but they thre
To him this mastir callis this squyer̉e
And seid him thus is redy our̉e sowꝑpere
Almost an our̉e it as I undir take
Syn̄ I ȝewe bad our̉e soper to make
Sir quod this squyer̉e when it likith ȝewe
It is al redy thogh yee wol right now
Go wee and sope for it is for the best
These amourouse folk som̄ tyme they must have rest
And aftir soper fil they in trete
What som shuld the Mastris guerdon̄ be
To remeve al the Rokkis in breteyn̄
And eke fro geround to the mounte of seyn̄
And made hym straunge and swore so God hym save
Les than a Mƚ pound wold he nat have
Ne gladly for that som he nold nat goon̄
Aurilius with gladful hert anon̄
Seyd thus fy on thowsand pound
The wide world wich men sey is round
I wold it ȝeve yf I wer̉e lord of it
This bargeyn̄ is ful dryve ⁊and ful knyt
Yee shul be paid trewly be my trowith
But lokith nowe for no necligence ne slowith
Yee tary us her̉e no leng̉er þan to morowe
Nay quod the Clerk have her̉e my feith to borowe
To bed he both Aurilius whan him list
And wel myȝe al that nyght he had rest
What for his bargeyn̄ and for his hope of blis
His woful hert of penᵃaunce had a lis
Oppon the morowe when it was day
To Breteyn̄ toke they the right wey
Aurilius and this Magycien be side
And by assent ther̉e they wold abide
As this was as the book doith remembir
The cold Frosty seson̄ of Decembir
Phebys wex hewid like latoıı̄un
That in his hoot declynacioun̄
Shone as the burnyd Gold with stremys bright
But in Caprecorn̄ adoun̄ he light
Wher̉e as he shon̄ ful pale I dar̉e wele seyn̄
The bitt̉er frostis with the slet or reyn̄
Distroyid hath the grene in every ȝerd
IAnuar̉e sit be the fiẻe with dobbil berd
And drinkith of his Bugil horn̄ þe wyne
And aftir̉e this Ale both good and fyne
At Cristmas crijth every lusty man̄
Aurilius doith al that he can̄
To wayte a tyme of this conclucioun̄
This is to sey to make illucioun̄
Be such apparence Iogolory
I can no termys of Astrology
They shewid that every white shuld wen̄ ⁊and sey
That of Breten̄ the Rokkis wer̉e a wey
Or ellis they wer sonkyn̄ undir the ground
So atte last he hath his tyme I found
To make his Iape and his urecchidnes
Of such a suꝑpersticioun̄ of cursidnes
His tablis tollentanys forth he broght
Ful wele correctid it lakkid noght
Nethir̉e his colet nethir̉e his expans ȝeris
Ne his rothis ne his othir̉e geris
And be his centris and his argumentis
And his proporcionel conetentis
For his equaciouns in every thyng
And be his viij sper̉e in his working
He knewe wele howe fer̉e anath was sowe
For the hede of that fixe Aries above
That in the iij sper̉e concederid is
Ful subtilly he calkelid al this
When he had his first mancioun̄
He knewe the remnaunte be proporcioun̄
And knewe the rising of the mone wele
And in whose fase and Iin̄ everidele
And knewe wele the manys mancioun̄
Accendent to his opperacioun̄
And knewe also his othir̉e observauncis
For wich illucioun̄ and such myschaunsis
As hethen folk usedyn in tho dayis
For such no longir makith her̉e delayi
But thorowe his magik a wook or twey
It semed as al the Rokkis wer̉e a wey
Aurilius ȝit wich that dispeyrid is
Whethir he shal haue his loue or fare amys
Awaytith nyght ⁊and day on this myrakil
And when he knewe that þ̉ree was non̄e obstakil
That voydid wer̉e these Rokkis euerichon̄
Down̄ to this mastris feet he fil anon̄
And seid I voful vrech Aurilius
Thank ȝewe lord and my lady venus
That me have holpyn̄ fro my caris cold
And to the Tempil forth hath he hold
Wher̉e as he knewe he shuld his lady se
And when̄ he sy his tym̄ anon̄ right he
With dredeful hert and humbil cher̉e
Salowyd hath his soueren lady dere
My rightful lady quod this vsful man̄
Whom I most drede and loue as I best can̄
And lothest wer̉e of al this world displese
Ner̉e it for ȝewe I have so grete disese
That I must dy her̉e at yeur̉e foot anon̄
Not wold I tel ȝewe howe me is wo begon̄
But certis othir̉e I must dy or pleyn̄
Yee slee me giltlese for verry peyn̄
But of my deth thogh yee have no rowith
Thenkith nowe wele oppon̄ yeur̉e trowith
And repent ȝewe for that God above
Er yee me slee be cause þat I ȝewe love
For madam̄ wel yee weet what yee have hight
Not that I chaleng ony thing of right
Oh ȝewe my soveren̄ lady but of yeur̉e grace
But in a gardyn̄ ȝondir in such a plase
Yee weet right wele what yee be hight me
And in my hond yeur̉e troqith pliȝt yee
To loeve me best God woot yee seid me s
Al be it that I unworthy be ther̉e to
Madame I speke for the honour̉e of ȝewe
More than to save my hertis lyfe right nowe
I have I do so as yee comaundid me
And yf yee uouch save yee may se
The doth yf ȝewe list have ȝeur̉e hest in mynd
For quyk or dede trewe shul yee me fynd
In ȝewe lyth al to do me lyve or dy
But wel I woot the Rokkis ben̄ a wey
He takith his love and she astonyid stode
In al her̉e fase nas o drop of blode
She wend nevir̉e to com in such atrap
Alas quod she that evir̉e this shuld happ
For wend I nevir be possibilite
That such a mervel myght be
That is a ȝenst the proces of natủe
And home she goith a sorowful creatur̉e
For verry feer̉e vnneth may she goo
She uepith and waylith a day or to
And swownyth that rewith it was to se
But why it was to no man̄ told she
For out of Town̄ was goon̄ Arueragus
But her̉e of she spak and seid this
With fase pale and sorowful chere
In her̉e compleynt as yee shul aftir̉e her̉e
Alas quod she on the fortune I pleyn̄
That I unware me urappid hast in thy cheyn̄
Fro wich I to skape I woot no socour̉e
Save only deth or dishonour̉e
On̄ of these to be hovith me to these
But nevirles ȝit had I levir̉e sese
My lyfe than of my body have a shame
Or make my self fals or lese my name
And with my deth I may be quyt I wi
Hath ther̉e nat many a nobil wyfe or this
And many a maid sleyn hem self alas
Rathir̉e than with her̉e body don̄ trespas
Ȝis certis these storys berith witnes
When · xxx teruntis ful of cursidnes
Had I sleyn̄ Phidon̄ atta Fest
They comaundid his doghters for to arest
And bring hem forth al in dispite
Al nakid to ful fil her̉e foule delite
And on her̉e Fadirs blode þey made hem daunce
Oppon the pavement God ȝeve hem myschᵃaunce
For wich the uoful madins ful of drede
Rathir̉e than they wold lese her̉e maydenhede
They be pryvyly stert in to a wel
And dround hem self as the bokis tel
¶ They of Meten̄ lete enquer̉e and seke
Of Lacedome · fifty maydins eke
On wich they wold have don̄ her̉e lechery
But was ther̉e non̄ of al that company
That she nas sleyn̄ and þat with glad entent
Ches rathir̉e for to dy than to assent
To ben̄ oppressid of her̉e maydynhede
Why shuld I than to day be in drede
¶ Loke eke the Teraunte Arostoclides
That lovid a maid that hiȝte Stymphalides
When̄ her̉e Fadir̉e sleyn̄ was on anyght
Vn to Dyanes goith she ful right
And hent the Image in her̉e hondis of her̉e myght rase
Til she was sleyn̄ right in the plase
Nowe sithins that maydins had such dispite
To be defowlid with mannys delite
Wel oght a wyfe her̉e self rathir̉e sle
Than be defowlid as thinkith me
What shal I sey of hasdribaldis wyf
That at Cartage be rast her̉e self her̉e lyfe
When that she sawe the Romayns wyn þe Town̄
She toke her Childryn̄ al and skippid a doun̄
In to the fier̉e and chase rathir̉e to dy
Than̄ ony Romayn did her̉e vylony
¶ Hath nat Lucres sleyn̄ her̉e selve alas
At Rome for she oppressid was
Of Torquyn̄ for her̉e thoght it was ashame
To lyve when̄ she had lost her̉e name
¶ The · vij · maydyns of Melesses also
Have sleyn hem self for verry drede ⁊and woo
Rathir̉e than folk of Galele hem shuld oppres
Mo than athowsand storyes I ges
Coude I tel as towching this mater̉e
When̄ Hellereda was sleyn̄ his wyfe so der̉e
Her̉e selve slowȝe and lete her̉e blode to glide
In Hellereda woundis wyde
And seid my body atte lest wey
Ther̉e shal no white defowle it yf I may
What shal I of mo ensanmples seyn̄
But so many have hem self sleyn̄
Wel rathir̉e than they wold defowlid be
I wol conclude that is best for me
To sle my self than be defowlid thus
I wol be trewe to Arueragus
Or rathir̉e sle my self in som̄ maner̉e
As did Demciens doghter̉e der̉e
Because she nold defowlid be
Of Tedasus it is ful gret pete
To rede howe thy doghter died alas
That slogh her̉e selve in such amaner̉e case
As grete pete was or wel more
The Theban̄ maide that for Nychamore
Her̉e selve slowȝe for such maner woo
And anothir̉e Theban maydyn̄ Right so
For on of Macedonie had her̉e ovir pressid
