div.l: She with her̉e deth her̉e maydynhode redressid
What shuld I sey of Maceratis wyfe
That for such a case be raft her̉e self her̉e lyfe
Howe trewe was eke Alciabades
His love þat for to dy rathir̉e chese
Than for to suffir his body vn burid be
Wich a wyfe was Alceston̄ quod she
What seith Omer̉e of Penelope
Al grece knowith of her̉e chastite
Parde of Lacedomea is urityn̄ thus
That when at Rome was sleyn̄ Protholomꝰus
No lengir wold she lyvyn̄ aftir his day
The same of nobil Ꝓrothenna tel I may
With out Brutus coud she nat leue
To whom̄ she had al her̉e hert I ȝeve
The ꝑparfite wyfe od Arthemessie
Honowrid is thorowe al ba\r/barie
On Teuqmes thy verry chastite
To al uivis may a myrrour̉e be
Thus pleynyth Dorregen̄ a day or tweye
Purposing evir̉e that she wold dey
But netherles oppon the third nyght
Hom̄ comyth Arueragus this worthy knyght
And axith her̉e why she wepith so sore
And she gan̄ wepin evir leng̉er the more
This husbond with glad cher̉e in spedely wise
Answerd and seid as I shal ȝewe devise
Is ther̉e oght ellis Dorrigen but this
Nay nay quod she God help me so I wis
This is to mykil ner̉e it wer̉e Goddis wil
Ȝee wyfe quod he let slepin þat is stil
It may be wele ȝit ꝑparventur̉e to day
Yee shul ȝeur̉e trowith hold be my fay
For God so wisly have mercy on me
I had wel levir stikid for to be
For verry love wich I to ȝewe have
But yee shuld yeur̉e trowith kepe ⁊and save
Trowith is the hiȝest thing that man may kepe
But with that word she brest out ⁊and wepe
And seid I ȝewe for bede oppeyn̄ of deth
That nevir while ȝewe lastith ony breth
To no white tel ȝewe of this mysaventur̉e
As I may best I wol my woo endur̉e
Ne make no contenaunce of hevynes
That folk of ȝewe may deme harm̄ or ges
And forth be clepith a Squier̉e ⁊and a maide
And right thus to hem̄ he seid
Go forth he seid with Dorrigen̄ anon̄
And bringith her̉e to such aplase anon̄
But they ne wist why she þidir went
He wold no white tel his entent
This Squyer̉e wich hiȝt Aurilius
On Dorrigen̄ that was so amerous
Of aventur̉e happid her̉e to mete
Amyd the Toun̄ right in þe quikkest strete
As she was bon̄ to go þe wey forth right
Toward the Gardyn ther̉e as she had hight
And he was to þe Gardin ward also
For wele he spyed when she wold go
Out of her̉e house to ony maner̉e plase
But thus they metyn̄ be aventur̉e ⁊and grace
And he salowith her̉e with glad entent
And axid of her̉e wedir ward she went
And she answerd half as she wer̉e mad
Vn to the Garden̄ as my husbond bad
My trowith for to hold alas alas
Aurilius gan wondir in this case
And in his hert had grete compassioun̄
Of her̉e cher̉e and of her̉e lementacioun̄
And of Arueragus the worthy knygh
That bad her̉e hold that she had hight
So looth hym was his wyfe shuld breke her̉e trowith
And in his hert he caght of this grete rowith
Concedering the best on every side
That from that lust ȝit wer̉e hym levir abide
Than to do so grete a urecchidnes
Ageyn Fraunchesy and gentilnes
For wich in fewe wordis seid he thus
Madame sey to yeur̉e lord Arueragus
That sith I se his grete gentilnes
To ȝewe and eke I se yeur̉e distres
That he is loth be shamyd ⁊and it wer̉e rewith
That ȝee to me shuld breke yeur̉e trewith
And ȝit had I levir evir to suffir woo
Than I depart the love be twixe ȝewe to
I ȝewe reles madam̄e in yeur̉e hond
Quyte every suyrment and every bond
That yee have made to me as her̉e be forn̄
Sithyn̄ that tyme þat yee wer̉e I born̄
My trowith I pliȝt I shal ȝewe nevir̉e repreve
Of non̄ be hest but her̉e I take my leve
As of the trewest and the best wyfe
That evir ȝit I knewe in al my lyfe
But every wyfe be ware of her̉e be hest
On Dorregen̄ remembr̉e atte lest
Thus can a Squyer̉e do a gentil dede
As wel as can a knyght with outyn̄ drede
She thankid hym oppon her̉e kneis bare
And hom̄e to her̉e husbond is she fare
And told hym̄ al as yee have herd me seid
And be yee sikir þat he was wel apaid
That it wer̉e impossibil me to urite
What shuld I lengir of þis case endite
Arueragus and Dorregen̄ his wyfe
In soveren blis ledyn̄ forth her̉e lyf
Nevir aftir was ther̉e angir hem be twen̄e
He chersith her̉e they she had be a quene
And she was trewe to hym for evir more
Of these to folk of me yee gete no more
Aurilius that his cost hath al for lorn̄
Cursith the tyme that evir he was born̄
Alas alas quod he that I be hight
Of purid Gold a thowsand pound weyȝt
Vn to this Philisophir̉e howe shal I do
I se no more but þat I am for do
Myn heritage I must nedis sel
And be abegg̉er for her̉e may I nat dwel
And shamyn al my kynrede in this plase
But I of hym myght gete som̄e grace
But netherles I wol of hym asay
And certen ȝeris and dayis for to pay
And thank hym of his grete curteȝie
My trowith wol I kepe I wol nat ly
With hert sore he goith un to his Cofir̉e
And broght Gold un to this Philisophr̉e
The ualowe of .v. hundrit pound I ges
And hym besechith of his gentilnes
To graunt hym dayis of þe remnaunt
And seid Mast̉er I dare wel make a uᵃaunte
I faylid nevir̉e of my trowith as ȝit
For sikirly my det shal be quyt
Toward ȝewe howe evir that I fare
To go a begging in my kirtil bare
But yee wold uouch save on suyrte
To ȝeer̉e or thre to respite me
Than wer̉e I wele for ellis must I sel
Myn̄ heritage ther̉e is no more to tel
This Philisophir̉e sobirly answerd
And seid thus when he his wordis herd
Have I nat hold covenaunt un to th
Ȝis certis wel and trewly quod he
Hast þowe nat had thy lady as þe likith
No no quod he and sorowfully he sikith
What was the cause tel me yf than̄ than̄ þᵘou can̄
Aurilius his tale he be gan̄
And told hym al as yee have herd be fore
It nedith nat to reherce it ȝewe no more
He seid Arueragus of gentilnes
Had levir to dy in sorowe and distres
Than that his wyfe wer̉e of her̉e trowith fals
The sorowe of Dorregen he told hym als
Howe looth her̉e weer̉e to be a wiccid wyfe
And that she has levir alost her̉e lyf
And that her̉e trowith she swore þorowe Innocence
She nevir̉e erst had herd of apparence
That made me to have in her̉e so grete pete
And right as frely as he sent her̉e me
As frely sent I her̉e hym̄ ageyn̄
This is al ⁊and som̄ ther̉e is no more to seyn̄
This Philisophir̉e answerd leve brothir
Everich of ȝewe did gentilnes to othir
Thowe art a Squyer̉e and he is a knyght
But God for bede for his blesful myght
But yf a Clerk coud do agentil dede
As wel as ony of ȝewe it is no drede
Sir I reles thy thowsand pound
As right nowe thowe wer̉e cropyn̄ out of þe ground
Ne nevir or nowe thowe haddist knowyn̄ me
For ʆsir I wol nat take apeny of the
For al my craft ne for al my travaile
Thowe hast wel paid for my uitaile
It is I nowe far̉e wel ⁊and have good day
And toke his hors ⁊and forth he ridith his way
Lordingis this questioun̄ þan axe I ȝewe
Wich was the most fre as ȝinkith ȝewe
Nowe tellith me or yee ferther̉e wend
I can no more my tale is atta en
¶ here begynnyth the second Nonne her prolog
The minister and noryssh unto uicis
That men clepith in Englissh Idilnes
Wich that porter of the ȝate of delicisis
To eschewe be her̉e contrary hym to oppres
That is to sey be leful besines
Wel oght wee to do al our̉e entent
Les than the Fend thowwe Idilnes vs hent
For he with his thowsand cordis sliȝe
Contenuelly us waytith to be clap
When he may man in Idilnes espy
He can so lightly cach him in his trap
Til that a man be hent right be þe lap̄
He nys nat ware the Fend hath hym in hond
Wel oght us uerch and Idilnes with stond
And thogh men dredyn̄ nevir for to dy
Ȝit se men sele be reson̄ doutlese
That Idilnes is hoten̄ slogardry
Of wich ther̉e comyth nevir̉e no good encrese
And sen̄ that slowith her̉e holdith in alese
Only for to slepe and ete and drink
And to devour̉e al that othir̉e swynk
And for to puth us from̄ such Idilnes
That cause is of so grete confucioun̄
I have her̉e don̄ my feithful besines
Aftir the legend in translacioun̄
Right of thy gloryus lyfe and passioun̄
Thogōh with thy garlond uroght of Rode of lyly
The mene I maid and martir seynt Cecely
And thowe that flour̉e art of uirgyns al
Of whom that Bernard list so wele to urite
To the at my first begynnyng I cal
Thowe comfort of us urecchis do me endite
Thy maydyns deth that wan̄ thorowe þyhir̉e þy hir̉e merite
The etern̄ lyfe thowe graunt of þe Fend uictory
As men mowe aftir̉e rede in her̉e story
Thowe maid ⁊and modir doghter of thy son
Thow wel of mercy synful sowlis to cur̉e
In whom that God of bounte chas for to won̄
Thowe humbil and hiȝe afore every creatur̉e
Thowe noblist so ferforth our̉e natur̉e
That no disdeyn̄ the maker had of kynd
His son̄ in blode and Flessh to cloith ⁊and wynd
With in thy Cloystir blesful of thy entreis
Toke mannes shap the eternal love ⁊and pees
That of the tryne compas lord ⁊and guyde is
Whom heven ⁊and erth ⁊and se ouȝt to reles
Ay heyrien̄ and þowe uirgyn̄ of ủergines
Bare of thy body and dweldist mayd pur̉e
The creator of every creatur̉e
Assemblid is in the magnificence
With mercy goodnes ⁊and such pete
That thowe that art the son̄ of exelence
Not only helpist hem that preyith the
But oftyn̄ tyme of thy benignite
Ful frely or that men thy help be sech

be it so that Fortun Riches yee may hau much folk

ȝit
be houith nat ne it is nat good to be gyn wer wher
as yee may hau in othir maner pese vn to yeur worship
and honour ⁊and ꝑperfit

For the victorys that ben of batell
in this world lyth nat in grete nombir or multitud of
pepil
⁊and streng than was þe pepil of makabe

ȝit he re-
comfortid his litil pepil and seid in this wise

Also
lightly quod he may our lord God gyf uictory to alitil
pepil as to many folk

For the uictory of batel comyth
nat by a grete multitud of pepil

but it comyth fro oᵒ
lord God of heuyn

and der sir for as mych as þer
is no man in certen that it be worthy þat God ȝyf him
uictory or noght aftir that Salamon seith

Ther for
euery man shal gretly drede werris to be gyn

and be
cawse that in batellis fallith many perellis

⁊and happith
othir while that also son is the grete man sleyn as þe
litil man

And as is wrytyn in the second booke of ky-
ngis The dedis of Batellis ben Auenturis and
no thing certen

For as lightly is on hurt with a sper
as a nothir

and for ther is grete perel in wer Therfor
shuld a man oschewe and flee wer in as mych as
a man may goodly

For Salamon seith he that lo-
uith perel shal fal in perel ~~~//~~~~//

Aftir that dame prudence had spokyn in þis
maner Mellebe answerd and seid

I se wele
dam prudence that by feir wordis and resons
þat haue shewid me that wer likith ȝewe no thing
but I hau nat herd in þis counsel howe I shal do in þis nede

Certes quod she I counsel ȝewe that ye nede
a cord with yeur aduersarys that ye hau
pese with hem

For seynt Iam seith in his
Epistelis that be concord and pees þe final richessis
waxin grete

And by debate ⁊and discord the gret richessis
fallyn down

And yee know wel that on of þe grettest
⁊and most soueren thingis is in this world is vnite . ⁊and pes

And ther for seith our lord Ihıı̄un Crist to his appostelis
in this wise

wel happy and blessid be they that louyn
and pruchasyn pese For þey be callid Childryn of God

A quod Mellebe nowe se I wel that yee lou nat
myn nonour ne my worship .

yee knowyn that
myn aduersarie hau be gouyn þis debate

⁊and
sen wel that they ne requyryn ne preyn me of pese ne þey
axe nat to be reconsylid

wol ȝee make me go obey to
hem and cry hem mercy

For seith that wer̉e nat my wor-
ship

For right as men seyn that ouir grete homlynes
engendrith grete dispeyring so farith it be to gᵉte humilite ¶ or mekenes

Than be gan Prudence to make o
semblant of wreth and seid

certis sir sau ye
grace I lou ȝeur̉e honour̉e and yeur̉e profit as I
do myn own and euir̉e hath don

neþ̉er yee ne non othir
sawe nebir̉e the contrary

And ȝit yf I had seid that
yee shuld hau purchasid the pees ⁊and þe reconsiliacion
I ne had mych mystakyn me ne seid a mys

For þe
wise man seith The discencon be gynnyth be a nothir
man a reconsiling be his self begynnyth

and þe ꝑparphet
seith fleith Shrewdnes and do goodnes

seke pese
and folowe it in as mych as in the is .

ȝit sey I nat þᵗat
yee shul rathir pursewe to yeur aduersarie for pese
þen þey shul to ȝewe

For I knowe wel I nowe þat yee
be aso herd of hert that yee wol do no þing for me

And Salamon seith that he that hath ouir̉e herd as
hert he atte last shal mys hap ⁊and mys be tide

A hem Mellebe had herd dame Prudence make
seblant of wreth he seid in this wise

dame
I prey ȝewe that yee be nat displesid of þin-
gis that I sey

For yee knowyn wel þat I am Angry ⁊and
wrotth and that is no wondir

þey I be wroth and
they þat ben wrotth woot nat wel what they don
ne what they seyn

Therfor þe ꝑparphet seith That
trobelid yeu hau no clere sight

But seith and
counsellith me as yewe likith For I am redy to do
right as yee wol desir

and yf y wol repreu me of
my foly I am the more hold to lou ȝewe ⁊and to preise
ȝewe

For Salamon seith he that reprouith him þᵗat
doith foly

he shal fynd gretter grace than he
that disseyuith him with swete wordis

Than seid Prudence I make no semblant of
wrath ne of angir but for yeur ꝑparphite

for
Salamon seith he is more wrorth þat repre-
sith or chidith a fole for his foly shewyng him sem-
blant of wreth

than he that supportith hym ⁊and prey-
sith him in his mys doyng ⁊and laghith at his foly

and þs sam Salamon seith aftirward þat by þe
sorowful visage of a man þat is to sey be þe sory
⁊and þe heuy coutenıı̄unce of a man
þe fool correctith him self

Than seid Mellebe I shal nat
con answer vn to so many feir resons and .
shewyn

seyth shortly yeur wil and yeur
counsel ⁊and J am redy to perfourm and ful fil hit

Than dame Prudence discouerid al her wil
vn to him and seid

I counsel ȝewe a bou
al þingis that yee make pese be twen God
and yew
and beith reconsilid vn to him ⁊and to his gᵘce

For as I hau seid to ȝewe be forn God hath suffrid
ȝew to hau this tribulacon ⁊and disese for yeᵒ synnys

and yf yee wol de as I sey vn to ȝewe God wol
send yeur aduersarys vn to ȝewe

⁊and makyn hem
to fal at yeur fete redy to do yeur wil ⁊and yeur com-
anndementis

For Salamon seith when þe condic̄etcōnn
of a man is plesant ⁊and lykyng vn to God

he chann-
gith the hertis of þe mennys aduersarys and con-
strynyth hem to be seke him of mercy ⁊and of grace

¶ And I prey ȝewe let me speke with yeᵒ aduersarys
pryuyly

For they shal nat know that it be yeur̉e
assent ne yeur wil

and than when when I know
her wil ⁊and her assent I may counsel yew þe more suyrly

Dame quod Mellebe do yeur wil ⁊and yeur lik-
yng

for I put me holy in yeur disposicon -
and ordinannce ~. // ~ // ~ // ~ // ~ // ~ // ~

When dame Prudence sawe þe good wil
of her husbond diliburid ⁊and toke auise in -
her self

thinkyng howe she myght bryng
this nede to a good concluson and to a good end

and when she sawe her tym she sent for thes
aduersarys to com to her vn a certen place

⁊and shewid
vusely vn to hem the grete goodnes that comyn of pees

⁊and
the grete harmes and perellis þat ben in werr

and seid to
hem in a goodly maner howe that them oghten to hau grete
repentunce

of the InIury and wrong that they had don to
Mellebe her lord and vn to her and her doghter ~~~~~

And when they herdyn the goodly wordis of dam
Prudence

they wer so suspirid and rauesshid and
had so grete Ioy of her that wondir was to tel

a lady quod they yee hau shewid vn to vs þe blessing
of swetnes aftir the sawe of dauid the ꝑparphet

for the re-
consiling wich we be nat worthy to hau in no maner

but
wee ont to requyryn it with grete contricon ⁊and humilite

þᵗat
yee of yeur goodnes hath presentid vn to vs

nowe so-
wel That the science and the connyng of Salamon ys
ful trewe

for he seith that swete wordis multiplien ⁊and
encresen Frendis and makyn shrewis to be debonair̉e and
meke

Certes quod they wee put al our mater ⁊and dede
and cawse in yeur good wil

and be redy to obey the co-
manndement of my lord Mellebe

¶And þerfor der ⁊and
benign lady we prey yewe and besech yewe as mych
as we can or mowe

that it like vn to yeur grete goodnes
to fulfillyn in dede yeur wordes goodly

For wee conce-
deryn and knowlechyn that we hau offendid and gᵉuid
my lord Mellebe out of mesur

so ferforth that we be
nat of power to make his amendis

and ther for we
oblegen vs and bynd vs and al our Frendis for to do al
his wil and his comanndementis

But þer auentur he
hath such heuynes and such wreth to vs ward be cawse
of our offence

that he wol enyon vs such maner of peyn
that we may nat bere it ne susteyn

And ther̉e for nobil
lady we be seke to yeur womanly pete

to take such a-
uisement in this nede That we ne our Frendis be not
disheritid and distroyid thorow our foly ~~~~~ ~~ ~~

Certes quod dame Prudence it is an hard thing
and a right perlus

þat a man put him al vicirly
in Arbitracon ⁊and Iugement ⁊and in the myght and
in the power of his enmyis

For Salamon seith leuith
me and gyu credence to that I shal sey . Quod he the
people folk and gouerners of holy Church .

Do thy son
to thy wyf . to thy Frend ne to thy brothir

neuir gyu the
mastre ouir thy body whilis thowe lyuist

⁊and Now sith he
defendith that a man shuld nat ȝeu to his brothir ne to
his Frend the myght of his body

By a strenger reson he
defendith a man to ȝeb him self to his enmy

And neþ̉erles
y counsel ȝewe that yee mystrust nat my lord

For I knowe
wele that he is debonair and meke and large ⁊and Curterse

and no thing Desyrous ne no thing Couertous of good ne
riches

For ther nys no thing in this world that he desirith
sau only worship and honour

Ferther I know I am ful
sur that he shal no thing do in this nede with outyn
my counsel

and I shal so work in this case that by the
grace of our lord God yee shul be reco9nsilid vn to vs

Than seid they with o bois worshipful lady
we puttyn vs and our goodis in yeur wil ⁊and
disposicon al fully

and be redy for to com
what day that yee like vn to yeur nobles for to lymyt
vs or assign vs

for to maken our obligacons ⁊and bondis
al so strong as it likith vn to yeur goodnes

þat we mow
fulfil the wil of ȝewe ⁊and of my lord Mellebe ~~~~~

When Dame Prudence had herd the answers
of these men she bad hem gon a ȝen pryuyly

and she returnyd vn to hir lord Mellebe ⁊and
told him howe she found his aduersarys ful repentıı̄unnt

knowleching ful lowly her synnys and trespas ⁊and howe
þey were redy to suffir al peyn

requyring ⁊and preyng him
of mercy and of pete ~~~~~ . /// ~~~~~~ /// ~~~~~~~~

Than seid Mellebe he is wel worthy to hau
pardon and forȝeunes of his synnys þat ex-
cusith him nat of his syn

but knowlech and
repentith him axing indulgence

For Senek seith ther
is the remission and forȝeunes wher as the confession
is
For confession is neyȝbour to Innocence

and þer for
I assent and conferm me to hau pese

but it is good þat
we do nahght with out þe wil ⁊and þe assent of our frendis

Than was Prudence right Ioyful and glad
and seid

Certis sir quod she I and wel and
goodly answerd

For right as by the counsel
assent and help of our Frendis yee hau before to
ueng ȝewe and make wer

right so with out her consel
shal yee nat acord ȝewe ne hau pees wᵗith yeur adversarys

For the lawe seith ther nys no thing so good be wey
of kynd as a thing to be vnbowndyn to him þat was
bound

and than Dame Prudence with out . delay or
taryng sent a non her message for her kyn ⁊and for her
old Frendis wich that ben trewe and wise

and told
hem be ordir in presence of Mellebe al this mater as
it is a bou expressid and declarid

and preyid hem
That they wold sey her auise ⁊and counsel and what
best wer to do in this nede

¶ and when Mellebeus
Frendis had taken her auise and diliberacon of the
forseid mater

and had examynyd it be grete besines
and grete dilligence

they ȝaf ful counsel for to hau
pese and rest

and that Mellebe shuld resseyu with good
hert his aduersarys to for ȝeunes and mercy

and
when dam Prudence had herd the assent of her lord
Mellebe ⁊and of his Frendis ⁊and howe the counsel
acordid

she
was right glad in her hert and seid

Ther is an old
prouerb quod she that seith That þe goodnes þᵗat þewe
maist do this day do it

and abid nat ne delay it not
til to morowe

and ther̉e for I counsel that ye send yeur
messagis such as ben distrete and wise

vn to yeur̉e
aduersarys tellyng hem on yeur be half

That and þey
wol trete of pees and a cord

that they shap hem wᵗith
out delay or taryng to com vn to vs .

wich thing þer-
fournyd was in ded

and when these trespassours and
repentyng folk of her folys that is to sey the aduer-
sarys of Mellebe

had herd what these messages seid
vn to hem

they wer right glad and Ioyful ⁊and answerd
ful mekely and benygnly .

ȝelding graces ⁊and þankis
vn to her lord Mellebe and to al his company

and
shopyn hem with out ony delay to go wᵗith þe messang
to obeyin the comanndement of her lord Mellebe

and right a non they toke her wey vn to her lordis coᵒt
Mellebe .

and toke with hem som of her trewe Frendis
to make feith for hem and for to ben her borowis

¶ And
when they wer com to the presence of Mellebe he seid
hem these wordis

¶ It stondith thus quod Mellebe ⁊and
soth it is that
causles and with out skil ⁊and resons yee -

hau don grete Iniurys and wrongis to me ⁊and to my wyf
Prudence and to my Doghter also

For yee hau entrid
in to my hows be vyolence

and hau do such outrage
that al men knowyn wel þat yee hau disseruid deth
and therfor wol I wete ⁊and knowe of ȝewe

whethir ye
wol put the punysshment ⁊and chastesing of þe uengıı̄unnce
of this outrage in þe wil of me and my wyf or nat .
Than the wysest of hem hanswerd ⁊and seyd

sir quod he wee knowen wel that wee be
vnworthy to com to the court of so grete a lord
and so worthy as yee ben

For wee hau so gretly mys
takyn vs and hau offendit and gilt in such a wise
a geyn yeur hiȝe lordship

that trewly we hau disʆseruid
the deth

But ȝit for the grete goodnes ⁊and debonairte
that al the world witnessith of yeur person

wee sub-
mit vs to to the exellence ⁊and beniginte of yeur gᵃcius
lordship
and be redy to obey to al yeur comanndement

Bsekyng ȝewe of yeur merciabil pete ye wol considir̉e
our grete repentunce ⁊and lowe submyssion

and grunt vs
forȝeunes of our outragius trespas ⁊and offencis

For wel
yee knowyn that yeur liberal grace ⁊and mercy strecchith
ferther in to goodnes þan doith our̉e outragius giltis
⁊and trespas in to wikkidnes

al be it that cursidly and
dampnably we hau a gilt a geyn yeur̉e lordship

Than Mellebe toke hem vp fro þe ground ful
benignly

and resseyuid her obligacons ⁊and
her bondis by her othis oppon her plaggis
and borowis

and assignyd hem a certen day to retorn
vn to his court

For to resseyu and accept the Iugement
that Mellebe wold comannd for to be don on hem
for the cawsis a forn seid ~~~~ // ~~~~~ / // ~~ ~~~~ //
>

And when Dame Prudence sawe her tym she
feynyd and axid her lord Mellebe

what
uengunce he thoght to take oppon his aduer
sarie .

t o wich Mellebe answerd and seid
certes quod he I think and purpose me fully

for to
disherit hem of al that euir they haue and for to
put hem in exile for euir more

Certes quod Dame Prudence this wer a cruel
centence and mych a geyn reson

for yee be rich I
nowe and hau no nede of othir mennys good

and yee myght ful lightly in this wise gete ȝewe a Couetouse
nam

wich is a uicious lyuyng and oght to be eschewid of
euery good man

For aftir the word of þe appostil Couetise
is root of al arinys

and þ̉erfor it wer bettir to ȝewe for to lese
so much good of yeur own þan for to takyn of her good in
this maner

For bettir it is to lese good wᵗith worship þan for
to wyn good with uylony ⁊and sham

and euery man oght to
do his dilligence ⁊and his besynes to gete him a good nam

and ȝit he shal nat only besy him in keping of his good
nam

but he shal also do som thing be wich he may re-
nouel his good name

For it is wrytyn þat þe old good-
loos of a man or goodn nam is son goon or passid when it
is not newid ne renouelid

¶ And as towchyng þat ye
sey that yee wol exile yeur aduersarys

that thinkith
me mych out of reson and a geyn mesure

concedering
the power þey hau ȝeue ȝewe oppon hem self

¶ And it
is writyn that he is worthy to lese his prynylage that
mys cosith the myght and power that is ȝif him

I set
case yee myght enyeyn hem that peyn be right ⁊and be lawe
wich I trowe yee may nat do

I sey yee myght nat put it
to exucucon perauentur

and then wer it like for to retorn
to wer as it was be forn

and þ̉erfor yf yee wol þat men
do yewe obeysannce yee must dem more curtesy

that is
to sey more esier pennce ⁊and Ingement

For it is writyn
that he that most curtesly comanndith to him . men most
obeyen

and ther for I prey ȝewe that in þis necessite ⁊and
in this neede yee cast yewe for to ouir com yeur hert

¶
For Senek seith . he that ouir comyth his hert ouircomyth
twyis

And Tullius seith þer is no þing so comenabil
in a grete lord

as when he is debonair̉e and meke and
apeysith him lightly .

¶ And I prey ȝewe that yee wel
for ber to do uengunce

in such maner that yeur good
name may be kept and conseruid

and that men may
hau cawse or mater for to preyse ȝewe of pete and of
mercy

and that yee hau no cawse to repent ȝewe of
thing that is don

For Senek seyth he ouircomyth in
an euil maner that repentith of his victory

Wherfor I prey
ȝewe that mercy be in yeur hert

to the effect and þe entent
that God al myghty haue mercy on ȝewe in his last Ingemeᵗ

For Seynt Iame seith in his Epistil Ingement with ontym
mercy shal be don to him þat hath no mercy onyr a noþ̉er white

When Mellebe had herd the grete skillis and resons
of Dame Prudence and her wise enformacons ⁊and
techingis

his hert gan enclyn to the wil of his
wyf concedering her trewe entent

Conformyd him a non
and assentid him for to werk aftir̉e her̉e counsel

and þankid
God of whom procedith al vertu and al goodnes that him
sent auise of so grete discrecon

¶ And when the day ca
that his aduersarys shuld a pere in his presence

he spak
to hem ful goodly and seid in this wise

Al be it so that
of yeur̉e pride and hy psumpcon ⁊and foly ⁊and of yeur neccligēns
⁊and vnkonnyng

yee hau mys born ȝewe ⁊and trespassid vn
to me .
ȝit for as much as yee for yeur grete humilite
and that yee be sory and reprentıı̄unnte of yeur giltes
hit constreynyth me to do yewe grace and mercy

wher-
for I resseyu ȝewe to my grace

And for ȝif ȝewe vitirly
al the offensis and Iniurys and wronges that yee hau
don a ȝenst me ⁊and myn

to this effect and to þis end
That God of his endles mercy

wol end tym of my dyng
For gyu vs our trespas that wee haue gilt vn to him
in this wrecchid world ..

For doutles yf wee be sory
and repentunt for our synnys ⁊and giltis wich that wee
haue trespassid in the sight of our lord god

he is
so free and so merciabil

that he wol for geu vs our gil-
tis

and bryng vs to the blis that neuir shal hau
an eND . Amen .. ~:~:~:~:~:~:~:~:~:

div.l: And here begynnyth the Monk his Porolg
When endit was the tale of Mellebe
And of Prudence and her benignite
Our Ost seid as I am feithful man
And be the precius corpus Madrian
I had levir than a barel of Ale
That good lefe my wyf had herd this tale
For she nys no thing of such pacience
As was this mellebe and his wyf Prudence
Be goddis bonys when I bete my knavis
She bringith me the grete clobbit stavis
And crijth sleith the Doggis everichou
And breke both bak and also bon
And yf that ony neyȝbour of myn
Wol nat in Chirch to my wyf enclyn
And be so hardy vn to her for to trespas
When she comyth home she ravmpith in my fase
And crijth fals coward wreke thy wyfe
Be corpus dıı̄uns I wol have thy knyf
And thowe shalt have my distaf ⁊and go spyn
Fro day to nyght she wol thus be gyn
Alas she seith that evir I was shape
To wed a mylksop or a coward ape
That wol be ovir led with every white
Thowe darst nat stond be thy vivis right
This is my lyfe with out I wold fight
And out atte dor a non I must me dight
And ellis I am lost but yf that I
Be like a wild lyoun fole hardy
I woot wel she wol do me sle som day
Som neyȝbour and than go her way
For I am perlous with knyf in hond
Al be it that I dare nat with her stond
For she is big in Armys be my feith
That shal he fynd þat her mys doith or seith
But lete vs pas a wey Fro this matere
My lord Sir monk he seith be mery of chere
For yee shul tel a tale trewly
Lo Rowchestir stondith her fast by
Ride forth my lord breke nat our game
But be my trowith I knowe nat yeur name
Whethir shal I cal ȝew my lord dan Iohn
Or Dan Thomas or Dane Albon
I vowe to God thowe hast a feir skyn
It is a gentil pastur ther þowe goist in
Thowe art nat like a penᵃnte gostler
Oppon my feith thowe art som officere
For be my fadir soule as to my dome
Thowe art a mastir when thowe art at hom
No pore Cloysterer ne non pore novis
But a governour vyly and vyse
And therwithal of brawn and of bonys
Awel faring persou for the nonys
I prey to God ȝev him confucioun
That first the broght in to Relyoun
Thowe woldist a be a tredfoule a right
Haddist thowe as grete lev as þowe hast myȝt
To perfourm al thy lust in engendrure
Thowe haddist be gotyn many a creature
Alas why werist thowe so wide a cope
God ȝev me sorowe and I wer a pope
Nat only thow but every myghty man
They he wer shore oppon his pan
Shuld have a wyf for al þis world is lorn
Religyoun hath take vp al the corn
Of tredyng and borel men be shrympis
Of febil treis ther comyth wrecchid Impis
This makith that our heyris ben so sklendir
And febil þat they may nat wel engendur
This makith that our wyvis vol a say
Relygyus folk for þe may bettir pay
Of venus paymentis than mowe wee
God woot ne lusshingbournys pay yee
But be nat wroth my lord þogh I pley
Ful oft in gam a soth hav I herd sey
This worthy monk toke al in pacience
And seid I wol do my dilligence

That his peynys wer importabil
And certenly the wrech was vnresonabil
For many a mannys guttis did he pyn
But from his purpose cursid and dampnabil
For al his smert he nold him restreyn
But bad a non parelyn his Ost
And sodynly or that he was ware
God dauntid al his pride ⁊and al his bost
For he so sore fil out of his chare
That al his lymys and his skyn to tare
So that he ne myght go ne ride
But in achare ~ men about him bare
Al for brosid both bak and side
The wrech of God him smote so cruelly
That in his body wikkid wormys crepe
And ther with al he stank so orybely
That non of al his meyne that him kept
Whethir so he wook or ellis slept
Ne myght nat of him the stynk endure
And in this myschef he waylid ⁊and eke wept
And knewe God lord of euery creatur
To al his Ost and to him self also
Ful waltsom was the stynk of his careyn
No man myght him ber to ne fro
And in his stynk and in his oribil peyn
He starf ful wrecchidly on a mownten
Thus hath this Robber and this homicid
That many a man made to wepe and pleyn
Such guerdon as longith vn to pride
The story of Alisaundir is so comun
That every white þat hath discrecou
Hath herd som what or half of his fortun
This wide world as in conclucoun
He wan be strengith and grete renoun
They were glad for pese vn to hem send
The pride of man and best he leyd a down
Wher so he cam in to the worldis ende
Comparison myght ȝit nevir be makid
Be twix him and a nothir conquerrour
For al this world for drede of him hath quakid
He was of knyghthode ⁊and of Fredom flour
Fortun him made the heyr of hy honour
Save wyf and womman no thing myght a swage
His high entent in Armys and labour
So was he ful of loving corage
What pete wer it to him they I ȝewe told
Of Darius and of a thowsand hundrit mo
Of princis Erlis kyngis bold
Wich he conquerid and broght hem to wo
I sey as fer as man ma ride or go
The world was his what shuld I more devise
For thogh I write or told ȝewe evir mo
Of his knyghthode it myght nat suffise
Twelve yeer he regnyd Macabe
Philippis son of macedon he was
That first was kyng of grece that contre
O worthy gentil Alsiaundir Alas
That evir shuld fal such a case
Empoysonyd of thy folk thowe were
Thy strong Fortun hath turnyd in to an ase
And for the ne wept she nevir a tere
She shal gef men teris to compleyn
To the of gentilnes and of Franchesie
That al the world wildit in his demeyn
And ȝit him thoght it mygh nat suffise
So ful was his corage and his Emprise
Alas she shal me help to endite
Fals Fortun and poyson to dispite
The which of al this woo I white
By wysdom manhode and hiȝ labour
From humbil hede and hyȝ mageste
Vp roos he Iulius the conquerour
That al the occident be lond and se
Be strengith of hond or ellis be trete
And vn to Rome made him tributory
And sith of Rome Emperour was he
Til fortun wex his adversary
O myghty Cezar that in Thesale
As fer as that the day begynnyth to dawe
They þowe þorowe knyght hast take and slawe
Save fewe folk that with pompeyus fled
Thorowe wich thowe puttist al þe oryent in awe
Thank Fortun that so wel the sped
But nowe a litil while I wold be waile
This Pompeyus this nobil governoure
Of Rome wich that fly at this bateil
I sey one of his men a fals treytour
His hede of smote to wyn him favour
Of Iulius and him the hede broght
Alas Pompey of the oryent conquerroᵒʳ
That Fortun vn to such a fyn the broght
To Rome a yeen reperith Iulius
With his trihumphe lawriat ful high
But on a tym Brutus Cassius
That evir had of his hiȝe estate envy
Ful pryuyly had made conspirisy
Aȝenst this Iulius in subtile wise
And cast the place in wich he shuld dy
With boydkyns as I shal yewe devise
This Iulius vn to the Chapitil went
Oppon A day as he was wont to goon
And in the Chapitil A non him hent
This fals brutus on him ful son
And stikid him with boddekyns a non
With many a wound and thus they lete him ly
But nevir he gruᵃnt at no stroke but at on
Or ellis at to but yf his story ly
So manly was this Iulius of hert
And so wel lovid estatly honeste
That thorowe his dedly woundis so sore smert
His mannel ovir his hⁱppis kist he
For no man shuld se his pryvyte
And as he lay in dying in a traunce
And wist verrely that dy shuld he
Of honeste ȝit had he remembrᵃunce
Lucan vn to this story writith word ⁊and end
Howe that these copnquerouris too
Fortun was first frend ⁊and sithyn fo
No man trust oppon his favour long
But have her in avait for evir mo
Witnes of al the conquerours strong
The rich Cressus som tym kyng of lide
Of wich Cresus Cirius sore him dred
Ȝit was he caght a myd al his pride
And to bren men to fier him broght
Buty such a reyn down fro the firmament shade
That queynt the fier and made him to skape
Butte to be ware ȝit no grace he had
Tyl fortun on the galows made him gape
When he Escapid was he cowd nat stynt
For to be gyn a newe A ray a yen
He wend wele for that fortun him sent
Such þat he A skapid thorowe the reyn
That of his fois he myght nat be sleyn
And such a swewyn oppon a nyght he met
Of wich he was so prowd and eke so feyn
That in vengᵃunce he al his hert set
Oppon a tre he was as him thoght
Ther Iubiter him wissh both hals and side
A phebus eke a fair towel him broght
And drijd him wᵗith and ther wᵗith wex he prowd
And to his doghter that stode him beside
Wich þat he knewe in hiȝ Centence habound
He bad her tel her what it signifijd
And she his dremes right thus expounyd
The tre quod she the Galouse is to men
And Iubiter betokenyth snowe and reyn
And Phebus with his towel so clene
Tho ben the son stremys soth to seyn
Thowe shalt be hangit my fadir certeyn
Reyn shal the wassh and son shal the dry
Thus she warnyd ful plat ⁊and ful pleyn
His doghter that callid was phany
An hangit was cressus the prowd kyng
His rial trone myght him nat a vail
Tragedy is non othir maner thing
Ne can nat snyfy ne be waile
For that fortune alday wol asaile
With vnware strokis the regnes þat be prowd
For when men trust in her than wol she faile
And kyvir her bright fase with a clowd

l.hi: Here endith the Monke His tale

div.l: Here begynnyth the Nonnys Prestis Prolog
Nowe quod our Ost Sir no more of this
What yee have seid is right I now I wis
And much more for much hevynes
Is right I nowe to mykil folk I ges
Your talis do vs no disport ne game . ¶Prologg
Wher for Sir Monk or Dau Piers be yeur nam
I prey ȝewe hertly tel vs som what ellis
For sikir ner clynkyng of yeur bellis
That on yeur bridil hangith on every side
Be hevyn kyng that for vs al dyed
I shuld or this fal down for slepe
Al thogh the slowȝ had nevir be so depe
Than had yeur tale al be told in veyn
For certenly right as these clerkis seyn
Wher as a man may have non audience
Not helpith it to tel his centence
And wel I woot the substaunce is in me
Yf ony thing shal wel reportid be
Sir sey som what of huntyng I ȝewe prey
Nay quod this Monk I have no lust to pley
Nowe let a nothir tel as I have told
Than spak our Ost with wild spech and bold
And seid to the Nonnys Prest anone
Com hidir thowe Prest com hidir anone
Tel vs such thingis as may our hertis glade
Be blith thogh thowe ride oppon a Iade
What thogh thy hors be fowle and lene
Ȝyf he wol serve the rek nat a bene
Look that thy hert be mery evir mo
Ȝis Sir quod he also mot I go
But I be mery I wis I wol be blamyd
And right a non his tale he hath a tamyd
And thus he seid to vs everichon
This swet prest þis goodly man Sir Iohn

l.hi: Here endith the Nonnys Prestis Prolog
¶ Here begynnyth the Nonnys Prestis tale

div.l: A pore wydowe som dele steppid in age
Was som tym dwellyng in a narowe cotage
Besidis a grove stondyng in a dale
This wedowe of wich I tel ȝewe my tale
Syn that tym that she was last a wyfe
In pacience lad a ful simpil lyf
For litil was her Catel and her rent
By husbondry such as God her sent
She found her self and eke her doghtryn to
Thre large sowis had she and no mo
Thre kene and eke a shepe that hiȝt mal
Wel soty was her bour and eke her hal
In wich she ete many a sklendir mele
Of poynaunt sause she nedet nevir a dele
Ne deynte morsel passid non thorow her throte
Her diet was a corduᵃnte to her Cote
Repleccion ne made her nevir sik
A tempir diete was her fesik
And excersise and hertis sufficiaunce ¶
The gowt let her no thing to daunce
Ne replexion shent nat her hede
Ne wyn drank she non white ne rede
Hir bord was most servid with white ⁊and blak
Milk and white brede in wich she fond no lak
Seynt bacou and som tym an ey or twey
For she was a maner dey
A ȝerd she had enclosid al about
With dry stikkis and dich with out
In wich she had a kok hit Chaunteclere
In al the lond of Crowyng nas his pier
His vois was merier that the mery organ
On mas dayis that in the Chirch goon
Wel sikir was his crowyng in his log
Than is a Clok or ony Abbey horlog
Be natur he crewe ech assencou
Of the equynoxiou in the Town
For when degreis fiftene weer assentid
That Crewe he that it myght nat be a mendit
His Combe was redder than the fyn Coral
And batellid as it had be a Castel wal
His bil was blak and as gete it shon
Lik Asure wer his leggis and his ton
His naylis witter þan the lyly Flour
And like the burnyd Gold was his colour
This gentil Cok had in his governᵃnce
Vij hennys to do with his plesaunce
Wich weer his sustirs and his paramowris
And sondry lik to him as of Colowris
Of wich the feyrest hewid in the throte
Was clepid feir damesel pertelote
Curteys she was discrete and debonair
And compenabil and bare her self so fair
Syn that tyme that she was sevyn nyȝt old
That trulich she hath the hert in hold
Of Chauntecler lokyng in every lijth
She lovith him so that wel was him ther with
But such a Ioy ther was to her him syng
When the bright son gan to spryng
In swete a cord my lefe is fare in lond
For that tyme as I have vndirstond
Briddis and bestis cowd speke and syng
And so bil that in the dawenyng
When the bright son gan to spryng
Chauntecler a mong his wyvis al
As man in dreme is drecchid sore
And when that pertelot þus herd him rore
She was a gast and seid hert dere
What eylith yowe to grone in this manere
Yee be a verry sleper fy for shame
And he answerd thus and seid Madame
I prey ȝewe þat yee take it for no grefe
Be God I met I was in such myschefe
Right nowe that my hert is sore afrite
Nowe God he my swewyn reche a right
And kepe my body out of foul prisou
I met that I romyd vp and down
With in our ȝerd wher I sawe abest
Was like an hound and wold a made arest
Oppon my body and wold a made me dede
His colour was be twix ȝelowe and rede
And tippid was his tayle and both his eris
With blak vn lik the remnᵃnte of his heris
His snowt smal with glowyn yen twey
Ȝit for his loke for fere al most I dy
This causith me my gronyng dowtlese
Awey quod she fy for shame hertlese
Alas quod she for by God a bove
Now hav yee lost myn hert and al my love
I can nat lov a coward be my feith
For certes what so ony man seith
We al desire yf it myȝt be
To have husbondis hardy wise and ffre
And secre no nygard ne no fole
Ne him that is a gast of every tole
Ne non awauntour be God a bove
Howe durst yee sey for shame vnto yeur love
That ony thing myght make ȝewe a ferd
Have yee no mannys hert and have a berd
Alas and con yee be aferd of swewenys
No thing but vanyte God woot in swevyn is
Swev
And
When
Certis this dreme wich I have met to nyght
Comyth of the grete superfluyte
Of yeur rede colour parde
Wich cawsith folk to drede in his dreme
Of arowis and of fier with rede lemys
Of rede bestis than wol hem bite
Right as the humour of malyncolite
Cawsith many a man in slepe for to cry
Al this comyth of mannys foly
And for fere of grete bollis and beris blake
Or ellis blak devillis wol him take
Of humours cowd I tel also
That workyn in slepe many a man mych woo
But I wol pas as lightly as I can
Lo Catou that is so wise a man
Seid he not thus ne do no fors of dremys
Nowe sir quod she when we fle fro the bemys
For Goddis love as takith som laxatyfe
Op perel of my sowle and of my lyfe
I counsel ȝewe the best I wol nat ly
That both of Colour and of malyncoly
Yee purge ȝewe and for yee shul nat tary
Thogh in this town be non appoticary
I shal my self to herbis tech ȝewe
That shal be for yeur hele and for yeur prowe
And in yeur ȝerd to herbis shal I fynd
The wich hath of her ꝓpropir kynd
To purgyn ȝewe be neth and eke above
For ȝete not this for Goddis own love
Yee ben right colerik of complexioun
Wher the son in his assencioun
Ne fynd ȝewe nat replete of humurs hote
For yf it do I dare wel ley a grote
That yee shul have a fevir terciane
Or an agewe that may be yeur bane
A day or to yee shul have degestiuis
Of wormes or yee take yeur laxatiuis
Of laurer Centory and fumetory
Or ellis of Eldryn berijs that growith therby
Of captuse or of Gay tre berijs
Of herb Ive that in yeʳ gardyn growith þᵗat mery is
Pik hem vp right as they growe ⁊and ete hem in
Be mery husbond for yeur fadir kyn
Dredith no dreme I can sey no more
Madame quod he grᵃunt mercy of my lore
But nethirlese as towching daun Catou
That hath of wisdom such a grete renoun
Thogh that he bad no dremes for to drede
Be God men may in old bokis rede
Of many a man more of Autoryte
Than evir was Catou so mot I the
That al the reverce seyn of this centence
And have wel foundyn be experience
That dremes ben significacions
As wel of Ioy as of Tribulacions
That folk endure in this lyfe present
Ther nedith to make of this no Argument
The verry prefe shewith it in dede
One of the grettest autours þat men rede
Seith thus that to felawis went
A pelgremage in ful good entent
And happid so they cam in a town
Wher as ther was grete congregacoıı̄un
Of pepil and eke strett of herbegage
That they ne fond as much as o cotage
In wich they both myght I logid be
Wherfor they mustyn of necessite
As for a nyght depart company
And ech of hem goith vnto his hostry
And toke hir logyng as it wol fal
That on of hem was logid in a stal
Fer in the ȝerd with Oxin in the plowe
That othir was logid wel I nowe
As was his aventure or ellis his fortune
That vs governyth al as in comune
And so be fil long or it wer day
This man met in his bed as he lay
Howe that his felowe gon oppon him cal
And seid alas for in an Ox stal
This nyght I shal be mordrid ther I ly
Nowe help me dere brothir or I dy
In al hast com to me he seid
This man for fere fro his slepe abreid
And when that he wakenyd of his slepe
He turnyd him and toke of this no kepe
Him thoght his dreme nas but avanite
Thus twyis in his sleping dremed he
And ȝit atte third tyme his felawe
Cam as he thoght and seid I am slawe
Be hold my blody woundis depe and wide
Arise vp erly in the morowe tide
And atte westgate of the Town quod he
A Cartful of dong ther shalt thowe se
In wich my body is hid ful pryvyly
Do that cart a rest and þat boldely
My Gold cawsid me my mordir soth to seyn
And told him every poynt howe he was sleyn
With a petouse fase pale of hewe
And trust wel his dreme he fond ful trewe
For on the morowe as son as it was day
To his felawe he toke the next way
And when that he cam to his Oxis stal
Aftir his felawe he be gan to cal
And the Ostelere answerd him a none
And seyd sir your felawe is a gone
As sou as day he went out of this town
This man gan fallyn in suspecioun
Remembring on his dremes that he met ¶
And forth he goith no lenger wold he let
Vn to the west gate of the town and fond
A dong cart went as it wer to dong lond
That was a rayid in the same wise
As yee have herd the dede man devise
And with an hardy hert he gan to cry
Vengaᵘnce and Iustice of this felony
My felawe mordrid is this same nyght
And in this Cart her he lijth vp right
I cry out on the mynstirs quod he
That shuld kepe and rewle this Cete
Harowe alas her lijth my felawe sleyn
What shuld I more vn to this tale seyn
The pepil out stert and kist þe cart to grownd
And in the myddil of the dong they fownd
The dede man that mordrid was al newe
O blessid God that art so Iust and trewe
Lo howe that thowe be wreyst mordir al way
Mordir wol out that se wee day be day
Mordir is so waltsom and so abominabil
To God that is so Iust and resonabil
That he wol nat suffir that it helid be
Thogh it a byde a yeer or to or thre
Mordir wol out this is my conclucoun
And right a non the mynstris of the town
Hath hent the Carter and so sore him peynyd
And eke the Osteler so sore engoynyd
That they be knewe her wikkidnes anon
And were on hangit be the nek bone
Here may men se þat dremys be to drede
And certes in the same boke I rede
Right in the next Chaptir aftir this
I gab nat so have I Ioy or blis
To men that wold have passid on the se
For certen cawsis in to fer contre
Yf that the wynd had nat be contrary
That made hem in a Cete for to tary
That stode ful mery on an havyn side
But on a day aȝen the evyn tide ¶ᵘ
The wynd began to blowe right as hem list
Ioly and glad they went to her rest
And Castyn hem ful erly for to rise ⁊and saile
Butto the to man fil a grete mervaile
The ton of hem in sleping thoght he lay
He met a wondir dreme a geyn the day
Him thoght a man stode be his beddis sid
Hym comaundyng that he shuld a bide
And seid him thus yf thowe to morowe wend
Thowe shalt be dreynt myn tale is atta end
He woke and told his felawe what he met
And preyd him his viage for to let
As for that day he preyd him forto abide
His felawe that lay be the beddis side
Gan for to lagh and skornyd him ful fast
No dreme quod he shal so my hert agast
That I wol let for to do my thingis
I set nat a strawe be thy dremyngis
For swevyns be but vanite and Iapis
Men dreme alday of Owlis and of Apis
And of many a mase ther with al
Men dreme of thingis þat nevir was ne shal
But sith I se that thowe wolt her a bide
And thus for slowthyn fully thy tide
God woot it rewith me and have good day
And thus he toke his lev and went his way
But er that he had half his cours I seylid
I note why ne what myschaunce it eylid
But casuelly the shippis botom rent
And Ship and man vndir the watir went
In sight of othir shippis it be side
That with hem saylid atte same tide
And therfor feir pertelot so dere
Be such old ensaumplis may thowe lere
That no man shuld be to rechelese
Of dremes for I sey the doutlese
That many a dreme is ful sore to drede
Lo in the lyfe of seynt Kenelm I rede
That was Kenulphus son the nobil kyng ¶
Of Merturik of Kenelm met a thing
A lite or he was mordrid on a day
His Mordir in his Avycoun he say
His Norice him expounyd everi dele
His swevyn and bad him for to kepe him wele
Fro tresou but he was but sevyn yer old
And therfor litil tale hath he told
Of ony dreme so holy was his hert
Be God I had levir than my shert
That yee had red his legend as have I
Dame Pertelot I sey ȝewe trewly
Macrobeus that writith the Avicioun
In Affrik of the worthy Cipyoun
Affermyth dremes and seith that they bene
Warnyng of thingis that men aftir sene
And ferthermore I prey ȝewe lokith wele
In the old testament of Danyele
Ȝif he held dremes ony vanite
Rede eke of Iesop and ther shul yee se
Wher dremes be som tym I sey nat al
Warnyng of thingis that shul aftir fal
Look of Egipt Kyng Daun Pharao
His baker and his Boteler also
Wher they ne felt non effect in dremes
Who so wol seke Actis in sondry Remys
May rede of dremes many sondry thingis
Lo Crisus wich that was of lide kyng
Met he not he sat oppon a Tre
Wich signifijd that he shuld hangit be
Lo her Adromecha Ectoris wyf
That day þat Ector shuld lese his lyf
She dremed on the same nyght be forn
Howe that the lyf of Ector shuld be lorn
Yf that day he went in to Bateile
She warnyd hym but she myght nat availe
He went for to fight netherlese
But he was sleyn a non of AChilles
But that tale is al to long for to tel
And eke it is ny day I may nat dwel ¶ᵘ
Shortly I sey as for conclucioun
That I shal have of this Avycioun
I sey advercite and sey Ferthermore
That I ne tel of laxatiuis no store
For they be venemus I woot it wele
I hem diffy I love hem nevir a dele
Nowe lete vs speke of mirth and stynt al this
Madame Pertelot so have I blis
Of o thing God hath sent me large grace
For when I se the bewte of your fase
And ben so skarlet rede a bout the yen
It makith al my drede forto dyen
For also sikir as Inprincipio
Mulier est hominis confucio
Madam the centence of this latou is
Womman is mannys Ioy and mannys blis
For when I fele a nyght your soft side
Al be it that I may nat on ȝewe ride
For yeur perch is made so narowe alas
I am so ful of Ioy and of solas
That I diffy both swevyn and dreme
And with that word he flijth a down fro þe bem
For it was day and eke his hennys al
And with a Chuk he gan hem al to cal
For he had found a Corn lay in the ȝerd
Rial he was he was no more a ferd
He federid Pertelot twenty tyme
And trade as oft er that it wer pryme
He lokith as it were a grym lyoun
And on his toyis he romyth vp and doun
Him deigned nat to set his foot to ground
He Chukkith when he hath a corn I found
And to him than ren his wyvis al
Thus rial is he as a Prince is in his hal
Leve I this Chauntecler in his pasture
And aftir wol I tel of his aventure
When that the month in wich þe world began
That hit march when God first made man ¶
Was complete and passid were also
Syn march be gan sevyn dayis and mo
Be fil that Chaunteclere in al his pride
His sevyn vyvis walkyng him be side
Cast vp his yen to the bright son
That in the signe of tawrus had I ron
Twenty degrees and one ⁊and som what more
And knewe be kynd and by no nothir lore
That it was Pryme And crewe with blesful stevyn
The son he seid is clombyn vnto hevyn
Twenty degrees and one and more I wis
Madame Pertelot my worly blis
Herkenyth this blesful briddis howe þey sing
And se the Fressh Flouris howe þey spring
Ful is my hert of revel and of solace
But sodynly him fil a sorowful cace
For evir the lattir end of Ioy is woo
God wote that worldy Ioy is son ago .
And yf a rether coud feir endite
He in a Cronicle savely myght it write
As for a soveren notabilite
Nowe every wise man let him herkyn me
The story is also trewe I vndirtake
As is the book of launcelot du lake
That wommen held in ful grete reverence
Nowe wol I turn a geyn to my centence
A Colfox ful of iniquite
That in the ground had wonyd yeris thre
